revision.text:
'''Bishop Joasaph''' (secular name '''Ivan Ilyich Bolotov''', {{lang-ru|Иоанн Ильич Болотов}}; 22 January 1761 – May 1799) was a Russian Orthodox missionary, bishop of Kodiak, vicar of Irkutsk diocese.
He came to [[Alaska]] as the leader of a group of [[Missionary|missionaries]] from the [[Valaam Monastery]] in 1794. Under very primitive conditions he and his [[monastic]] companions established the foundations of an [[Orthodox Church in America|Orthodox presence in North America]]. Called to [[Irkutsk]], he was consecrated the [[auxiliary Bishop]] of [[Kodiak, Alaska|Kodiak]], but did not survive a shipwreck on his return to Alaska.
==Life== ''Ivan Ilyich Bolotov'' (Russian Иоанн Ильич Болотов) was born on January 22, 1761, in the village of Strazhkov in the Kashin district of the [[Tver province|province of Tver]]. His father was the local [[priest]] in the village. His early education was at the [[ecclesiastical]] school at the [[monastery]] in Kashin. His education continued at the [[seminary|seminaries]] in Tver and [[Yaroslavl]], graduating with honors. After graduating he taught at the [[Uglich]] ecclesiastical school for the next four years. Deciding to enter a monastic life he joined the [[Tolga Monastery]] where he received his [[tonsure]] in 1786 and was given the name of ''Joasaph''.
Subsequently, he moved to a monastery in Uglich and then on to the Valaam. The dates of his [[ordination]] as a [[deacon]] and as a priest are not known. He was raised to the rank of [[archimandrite]] in 1783. When the call for assembling a missionary team to travel to remote Alaska was made, Fr. Joasaph was selected to lead the team based upon his accomplishments as a monastic. The team of ten consisted of Fr. Joasaph as leader, four [[hieromonk]]s, a [[hierodeacon]], two [[monk]]s, and two servitors. ([[#Sources|Chevigny]] 65)
The journey to Alaska took them ten months, nearly a year, before arriving in [[Kodiak, Alaska]], on September 24, 1794. There, they found conditions not as represented to them by [[Grigorii Ivanovich Shelikhov]], the promoter of the Alaskan enterprise. The village on Kodiak was more primitive than described and the church that was promised was not there. The monastics found many abuses between the Russians and the natives in the village about which Fr. Joasaph was compelled to report to the state and church authorities in Russia. Thus, an antagonistic environment grew between [[Alexander Andreyevich Baranov|Alexander Baranov]], the village leader, and Fr. Joasaph and his missionaries.
Notwithstanding the adverse conditions, Fr. Joasaph and his party of monks were very successful in evangelizing the natives and expanded their preaching and efforts to the mainland. Yet, reaching out to the natives involved dangers. Witness the [[martyr]]dom of Fr. [[Juvenaly of Alaska|Juvenaly]] in 1796.
In reviewing the situation of the mission, in 1796, the [[Holy Synod]] created an [[auxiliary see]] in Alaska and elected Fr. Joasaph as Bishop of Kodiak. It was 1798 before news and instructions for his elevation reached him. For his elevation to bishop, Fr. Joasaph needed to return to [[Irkutsk]], where he was consecrated on April 10, 1799. Bp. Joasaph's consecration was unusual in that, due to the isolation of Irkutsk from the Holy Synod, the Holy Synod provided instructions for Benjamin, [[Bishop of Irkutsk]], to perform the consecration of Fr. Joasaph alone. Thus was recorded the only known situation in the history of the [[Church of Russia]] where an episcopal consecration was conducted by a single bishop.
Bp. Joasaph was not to reach his new see as the perils of travel in the northern seas would result in his death. Bp. Joasaph and his companions, Hieromonk Makary and Hierodeacon Stephan, perished as their ship ''Phoenix'' met with a serious storm and sank near the Alaskan coast during May 21 to 24, 1799. The ship was also carrying an important cargo of both people and supplies for the Kodiak colony. Thus, its loss seriously set back both the Orthodox mission in Alaska and the colony. The Holy Synod took no action to replace Bp. Joasaph and in 1811 officially closed the Kodiak episcopal see. It would be some thirty years before another hierarch would be named to Alaska.
==Sources== *''Orthodox America 1794-1976 Development of the Orthodox Church in America'', C. J. Tarasar, Gen. Ed. 1975, The Orthodox Church in America, Syosett, New York *Hector Chevigny, ''Russian America — The Great Alaskan Venture, 1741 -1867''. New York: Viking Press, 1965.
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061004123547/http://www.oca.org/HSbiojoasaph.asp?SID=7 Biography of Bishop Joasaph (Bolotov)] from the [[Orthodox Church in America|OCA]]
{{Russian America}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bolotov, Joasaph}} [[Category:1761 births]] [[Category:1799 deaths]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Alaska]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox bishops in the United States]] [[Category:Bishops in Alaska]] [[Category:Christian missionaries in Alaska]] [[Category:Deaths due to shipwreck]] [[Category:People of Russian America]] [[Category:Russian Christian missionaries]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox missionaries]] [[Category:People from Kodiak, Alaska]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = John Stewart |honorific-suffix = |image = |image_size = |office = Member of the [[Western Australian Legislative Assembly|Legislative Assembly]]
of [[Western Australia]] |constituency = [[Electoral district of Claremont|Claremont]] |term_start = 29 September 1917 |term_end = 20 August 1918 |predecessor = [[Evan Wisdom]] |successor = [[Thomas Duff (politician)|Thomas Duff]] |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1868|5|23|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1927|8|30|1868|5|23|df=y}} |death_place = |party = [[Western Australian Liberal Party (1911–1917)|Liberal]] (to 1917)
[[Nationalist Party of Australia|Nationalist]] (from 1917) |religion = |alma_mater = |profession = }} '''John Stewart''' (23 May 1868 – 30 August 1927) was an Australian businessman and politician who briefly represented the [[Electoral district of Claremont|seat of Claremont]] in the [[Western Australian Legislative Assembly|Legislative Assembly]] of [[Western Australia]], from 1917 to 1918. Stewart was born in [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]], to Jeannie (née Moore) and Bruce Stewart. He arrived in Western Australia in the 1890s, and by 1897 was working as an accountant in [[Fremantle]]. In 1900, he founded a produce firm, John Stewart & Co., and subsequently became prominent in Fremantle's mercantile sector, serving as a president of the [[Fremantle Chamber of Commerce]].Black, David, and Bolton, Geoffrey (1990). ''[http://ncb.anu.edu.au/sites/default/files/documents/Bio%20Register%20of%20WA%20MPs%20Vol.1%201870-1930.pdf Biographical Register of Members of the Parliament of Western Australia: Volume One (1870–1930)]'', p. 105. At the [[Western Australian state election, 1914|1914 state election]], Stewart unsuccessfully contested the [[Electoral district of Fremantle|seat of Fremantle]] as a [[Western Australian Liberal Party (1911–1917)|Liberal]] candidate, opposing the [[Australian Labor Party (Western Australian Branch)|Labor]] government of [[John Scaddan]].[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28569744 "MR. J. STEWART'S CANDIDATURE."] – ''The West Australian'', 3 October 1914. He was defeated by Labor's [[William Carpenter (Australian politician)|William Carpenter]], the sitting member, placing second (in front of another Liberal candidate) with 29.40 percent of the vote.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article44749296 "MR. CARPENTER ELECTED."] – ''The Western Mail'', 23 October 1914. A strong supporter of the war effort against Germany, Stewart resigned from the Fremantle Chamber of Commerce in June 1916 to protest its apparent unwillingness to bar "persons of enemy birth" from membership.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37435498 "MR. JOHN STEWART RESIGNS."] – ''The Western Mail'', 16 June 1916. Prominent in local [[Presbyterian Church of Australia|Presbyterian]] circles, he was a member of the boards of [[Scotch College, Perth|Scotch College]] and [[Presbyterian Ladies' College, Perth|Presbyterian Ladies' College]], each located in the seat of Claremont. Stewart stood for that electorate at the [[Western Australian state election, 1917|1917 election]], running as one of three [[Nationalist Party of Australia|Nationalist]] candidates.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27309797 "MR JOHN STEWART'S CANDIDATURE."] – ''The West Australian'', 29 August 1917. He placed second on first preferences, but on the [[Two-party-preferred vote|two-candidate-preferred vote]] eventually won on a majority of just two votes, following a recount.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37996524 "MR. STEWART SUCCESSFUL"] – ''The Western Mail'', 5 October 1917. Stewart's time in parliament, however, was short-lived, as he resigned due to ill-health less than a year after taking office.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27487444 "RESIGNATION OF MR. STEWART."] – ''The West Australian'', 21 August 1918.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article81365317 "MR. JOHN STEWART, M.L.A. RESIGNS CLAREMONT SEAT."] – ''The Daily News'' ([[Perth]]), 20 August 1918. The [[Claremont state by-election, 1918|resulting by-election]] was won by another Nationalist, [[Thomas Duff (politician)|Thomas Duff]].[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article92744262 "CLAREMONT BY-ELECTION"] – ''Kalgoorlie Miner'', 14 September 1918. Stewart had married Lily Berry Tate in June 1897 in Fremantle, and the couple went on to have four sons and a daughter together. Later becoming residents of [[Cottesloe, Western Australia|Cottesloe]], the couple left for an extended tour of Europe in 1926. On the return voyage to Australia, on the [[SS Narkunda|SS ''Narkunda'']] in late August 1927, they were at sea near [[Gibraltar]] when Stewart jumped from a porthole wearing only his pyjamas. Both he and an engineer who had dived after him were drowned, and an inquest returned a verdict of suicide, brought on by "acute insomnia and [[neurasthenia]]".[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article58333422 "COTTESLOE RESIDENT DROWNED"] – ''The Sunday Times'', 4 September 1927. Aged 59 at the time of his death, Stewart was eulogised in ''[[The West Australian]]'' as a "capable business man" and "generous donor", "possessing gifts above the average".[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32049773 "SUICIDE AT SEA."] – ''The West Australian'', 1 September 1927. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stewart, John}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1927 deaths]] [[Category:Australian politicians who committed suicide]] [[Category:Australian Presbyterians]] [[Category:Businesspeople who committed suicide]] [[Category:Members of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly]] [[Category:Nationalist Party of Australia members of the Parliament of Western Australia]] [[Category:Politicians from Glasgow]] [[Category:Scottish emigrants to Australia]] [[Category:Suicides by drowning]] [[Category:People who died at sea]]

revision.text:
[[File:The Dubhlinn Gardens Garda Memorial Garden 04.JPG|thumbnail|right|150px|The [[Garda Síochána]] Memorial Garden, [[Dublin Castle]]]]
This is a '''list of Garda officers killed in the line of duty''' since the establishment of the ''[[Garda Síochána]]'' in 1922. The list includes all Gardaí who were killed in the service of the state (accidentally and unlawfully), as per the official '''Garda Síochána Roll of Honour'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=An Garda Síochána Roll of Honour List |url=http://www.garda.ie/Documents/User/media%20roll%20of%20honour.pdf |work=2010 |publisher=An Garda Síochána |accessdate=28 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528010615/http://www.garda.ie/Documents/User/media%20roll%20of%20honour.pdf |archivedate=28 May 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Garda Siochana Roll of Honour |url=http://www.policehistory.utvinternet.com/honour.html |work=2013 |publisher=Police History |accessdate=28 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627081200/http://www.policehistory.utvinternet.com/honour.html |archivedate=27 June 2014 |df= }}</ref> The list does not include members of previous police services or other [[Law enforcement in the Republic of Ireland|law enforcement agencies in the Republic of Ireland]], nor those in [[Northern Ireland]].
At least 23 serving Gardaí have been killed by individuals or groups associated with the Republican paramilitary groups,<ref>{{cite web|title=Terrorism|url=http://www.justice.ie/en/JELR/Pages/terrorism|publisher=Dept of Justice and Equality|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref> this being the most common cause of death apart from accidents.
The most recent death was that of [[Killing of Tony Golden|Garda Tony Golden]], who was murdered in October 2015, becoming the 88th member of the force to die on duty.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lally|first=Conor|title=Garda among two dead in Louth shooting|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/garda-among-two-dead-in-louth-shooting-1.2387868|accessdate=12 October 2015|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=12 October 2015}}</ref>
==Garda Síochána Roll of Honour== '''Note:''' Coloured rows denotes when officers were ''killed in the same incident''.

revision.comment: removed Harry Horsman as driver fatality (see Charles Swartz, a riding mechanic fatality); added note and references; fixed names, roles, and content of "Event" and "Car/Entry" cells; tweaked introduction, references, and "Fatalities by" tables among other things; added/updated/removed internal and external links; added/replaced/removed archivelinks; changed date format of archive dates to YYYY-MM-DD
revision.text:
This article lists the people who have been fatally injured in [[American open-wheel car racing|American Championship car racing]] during testing, practice, qualifying, or races since 1916, categorized into drivers, [[riding mechanic]]s, and non-participants. The lists show "IndyCar" or "Champ Car" fatalities that occurred in events making up the National Championship, which has been held by the following sanctioning bodies:
*[[AAA Contest Board|American Automobile Association]] (1916, 1920–1941, 1946–1955) *[[United States Auto Club]] (1956–1995) *[[Champ Car|Championship Auto Racing Teams]] (1979–2007) *[[IndyCar|Indy Racing League]] (since 1996)
The National Championship, which was split from 1979 to 2007, has featured regular races, non-points paying (non-championship) rounds, competitions sanctioned by entities that did not stage the National Championship in the same year (such as the [[Automobile Club of America]]), and the AAA [[Sprint car racing|Big car]] meetings held in the [[1946 AAA Championship Car season|1946 season]].
The most recent driver to be killed in an [[IndyCar Series]] event was [[Justin Wilson (racing driver)|Justin Wilson]] at the [[2015 ABC Supply 500]].

== Fatalities among non-participants == This section includes racers participating in an event who were killed while on the sidelines.
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%" |- ! Name ! Date of accident ! Sanction ! Track{{refn|group=note|name=track}} ! Event ! Session ! Role ! H.|Speer|nolink=1}}|USA|1912}} |April 8, 1916 |[[AAA Contest Board|AAA]] |[[Grand Boulevard (Corona)|Grand Boulevard]] ([[Corona, California|Corona]]) |Corona Grand Prize{{refn|group=note|name=NC}} |Race |Policeman |Due to tire damage [[Bob Burman|Bob Burman's]] racer skidded, turned over and dashed into a crowd of people, several of whom were injured. Burman, his mechanician Erick Schrader, and a policeman died.<ref name=GaT /> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Harold|Edgington|nolink=1}}|USA|1912}} |rowspan=3|November 18, 1916 |rowspan=3|[[Automobile Club of America|ACA]] |rowspan=3|[[Santa Monica Road Race Course]] |rowspan=3|[[1916 American Grand Prize|American Grand Prize]] |rowspan=3|Race |Spectator |rowspan=3|With the left front wheel having collapsed, [[Lewis Jackson (racing driver)|Lewis Jackson]] missed a slight turn. His auto slid along the roadside and struck several people, three of whom fatally. Jackson died when he was pinned against a tree.<ref name=NYT3 /> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Leslie|Jenkins|nolink=1}}|USA|1912}} |Camera operator |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Lena|Juratsch|nolink=1}}|USA|1912}} |Street vendor |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Hughie|Hughes}}|UK}} |December 2, 1916 |[[AAA Contest Board|AAA]] |[[Uniontown Speedway]] |Universal Trophy{{refn|group=note|name=NC}} |Race |Driver |[[Frank Galvin (racing driver)|Frank Galvin]] lost control of his racer, smashed through the guard rail and slammed into the press stand, injuring several of its occupants and crushing to death Hughie Hughes, who had crashed out of the race himself and was standing by the press box. Galvin, who succumbed two days later, and Gaston Weigle, his mechanician, were also killed.<ref name=PP /> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Bert|Shoup|nolink=1}}|USA|1912}} |May 30, 1923 |[[AAA Contest Board|AAA]] |[[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] |[[1923 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]] |Race |Spectator |[[Tom Alley]], relief driving for [[Earl Cooper]], slid, rolled over and penetrated a fence, killing a 16-year-old spectator and hurting two other boys and himself.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thousands witness auto speeders race|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bGAtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=adkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6699%2C6922107|newspaper=[[Ottawa Citizen|The Ottawa Evening Citizen]]|date=May 31, 1923}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Russ|Hughes|nolink=1}}|USA|1912}} |rowspan=2|November 29, 1923 |rowspan=2|[[AAA Contest Board|AAA]] |rowspan=2|[[Beverly Hills Speedway]] |rowspan=2|250-mile race |rowspan=2|Pre-race |Photographer |rowspan=2|Attempting a start before the race, [[Harry Hartz]] hit a photographer, a team owner, and a mechanic, killing the former two and badly injuring the latter.<ref>{{cite news|title=George Wade killed by auto on race track|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iiIuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OJ8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1449%2C496185|newspaper=[[The Nevada Daily Mail|The Nevada Daily Mail and The Evening Post]]|date=December 1, 1923}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|George|Wade|nolink=1}}|USA|1912}} |Team owner |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Dan|Shaw|nolink=1}}|USA|1912}} |October 12, 1925 |[[AAA Contest Board|AAA]] |[[Rockingham Park#Motor racing venue|Rockingham Speedway]] |Autumn Classic |Practice |Mechanic |A broken steering knuckle caused [[Vic Spooner|Vic Spooner's]] car to overturn and strike his mechanic, who was standing in the pits. Spooner survived a concussion of the brain.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mechanic killed and driver hurt in Salem spill|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3433589/|newspaper=[[Altoona Tribune]]|agency=Associated Press|date=October 13, 1925|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180731201248/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3433589/death_of_race_car_mechanic_dan_shaw/|archivedate=2018-07-31|dead-url=no}}</ref> |- |nowrap| accident costs life of youth|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eckxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Y-IFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3369%2C5858647|newspaper=The Reading Eagle|agency=Associated Press|date=May 31, 1931}}</ref> |- and hurting eight other people.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mechanic killed in racing mishap|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-S4rAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QpoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3629%2C2154693|newspaper=Reading Eagle|agency=United Press|date=September 7, 1954}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|John|Masariu|nolink=1}}|USA}} |May 30, 1961 |[[United States Auto Club|USAC]] |[[Indianapolis Motor burning, ran over and killed a firefighter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Truck kills '500' guard|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yAIkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yRAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3273%2C5358369|newspaper=Milwaukee Sentinel|agency=Associated Press|date=May 31, 1961}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Red|Stainton|nolink=1}}|USA}} |April 13, 1969 |[[United States Auto Club|USAC]] |[[Marchbanks leapt back into the path of [[Mario Andretti|Mario Andretti's]] auto. The mechanic sustained head injuries and died two days later.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pit mishap mars victory for Andretti|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5cghAAAAIBAJ&sjid=W6AFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1611%2C8112004|newspaper=Reading Eagle|agency=Associated Press|date=April 14, 1969}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Track aide dies|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=d7VWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=d-kDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1425%2C184748|newspaper=The Spokesman-Review|location=Spokane, Washington|agency=Associated Press|date=April 16, 1969}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Armando|Teran|nolink=1}}|USA}} |May 30, 1973 |[[United States Auto Club|USAC]] |[[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] |[[1973 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]] |Race |Team member |Rushing to the scene of [[Swede Savage|Swede Savage's]] crash, a fire truck ran into and killed a crewman for [[Graham McRae]].<ref name=SHT2 /> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Lyle|Kurtenbach|nolink=1}}|USA}} |May 24, 1987 |[[United States Auto Club|USAC]] |[[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] |[[1987 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]] |Race |Spectator |A tire which had come off [[Tony Bettenhausen Jr.|Tony Bettenhausen Jr.'s]] racer was catapulted into the stands by [[Roberto Guerrero|Roberto Guerrero's]] car and fatally struck a spectator in the head.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spectator killed when hit by tire flying off track|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GyYhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RHAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6327%2C7827221|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|agency=Associated Press|date=May 25, 1987}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Jean-Patrick|Hein|nolink=1}}|CAN}} |September 2, 1990 |[[Champ Car|CART]] |[[Concord Pacific Place|Vancouver street circuit]] |[[Molson Indy Vancouver]] |Race |[[Motorsport marshal|Marshal]] |Having pushed [[Ross Bentley|Ross Bentley's]] stalled racer out of a chicane area, three track workers jumped into the path of [[Willy T. Ribbs|Willy T. Ribbs's]] car, which was coming around the corner. After colliding with its rear, two of them were flung through the air and sustained minor injuries. The third was hit and overrun by the left rear wheel, succumbing to head injuries several hours after being operated on.<ref>{{cite news|title=One track worker was critically injured and another broke...|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1990-09-04/sports/9009040338_1_bentley-ribbs-hein|newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=September 4, 1990|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120000917/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1990-09-04/sports/9009040338_1_bentley-ribbs-hein|archivedate=2013-11-20|dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Worker at B.C. race dies|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19900904&slug=1091188|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|agency=Associated Press|date=September 4, 1990|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110000850/http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19900904&slug=1091188|archivedate=2013-11-10|dead-url=no}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Gary|Avrin|nolink=1}}|CAN}} |July 14, 1996 |[[Champ Car|CART]] |[[Exhibition Place#Race course|Toronto street circuit]] |[[1996 Molson Indy Toronto|Molson Indy Toronto]] |Race |[[Motorsport marshal|Marshal]] |Because [[Jeff Krosnoff|Jeff Krosnoff's]] racer had touched wheels with that of [[Stefan Johansson]], it was catapulted into the air and fatally struck a track worker, who was positioned behind the wall lining the track, while on its way into the catch fence where it disintegrated on impact, the cockpit coming to a stop against the opposite wall. Krosnoff was killed, too. Another marshal was slightly hurt.<ref name=LJW /> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Kenneth|Fox|nolink=1}}|USA}} |rowspan=3|July 26, 1998 |rowspan=3|[[Champ Car|CART]] |rowspan=3|[[Michigan International Speedway|Michigan Speedway]] |rowspan=3|[[1998 U.S. 500 Presented by Toyota|U.S. 500]] |rowspan=3|Race |rowspan=3|Spectator |rowspan=3|On lap 175, [[Adrián Fernández]] slammed into the outside wall in the fourth turn. His right front wheel was torn off and hurled over the fence into the stands, killing three spectators and injuring six others.<ref>{{cite news|last=Glick|first=Shav|date=July 27, 1998|title=Three spectators die at U.S. 500|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/jul/27/sports/sp-7580|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120132220/http://articles.latimes.com/1998/jul/27/sports/sp-7580|archivedate=2012-01-20|dead-url=no}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Sheryl|Laster|nolink=1}}|USA}} |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Michael|Tautkus|nolink=1}}|USA}} |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Barry|Mobley|nolink=1}}|USA}} |rowspan=3|May 1, 1999 |rowspan=3|[[IndyCar|IRL]] |rowspan=3|[[Charlotte Motor Speedway|Lowe's Motor Speedway]] |rowspan=3|[[1999 VisionAire 500K|VisionAire 500K]] |rowspan=3|Race{{refn|group=note|name=Abandoned}} |rowspan=3|Spectator |rowspan=3|On the 59th lap, [[Stan Wattles]] crashed into the outside wall in turn four, shearing off both right-side wheels. [[John Paul Jr. (racing driver)|John Paul Jr.'s]] car hit one of them, propelling it over the fence into the stands. As a result, three spectators were killed and eight others, two of whom were children, suffered injuries. The race was abandoned before completing the necessary 104 laps to be official.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/0a5b23332af2c13a7c18c801932dd24e|title=3 race spectators killed by debris|last=Macenka|first=Joe|date=May 2, 1999|website=Associated Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140217012246/http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1999/3-Race-Spectators-Killed-by-Debris/id-0a5b23332af2c13a7c18c801932dd24e|archivedate=2014-02-17|dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.motorsport.com/indycar/news/irl-preliminary-charlotte-crash-details-outlined/27340/|title=IRL: Preliminary Charlotte crash details outlined|website=[[Motorsport.com]]|date=May 14, 1999|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140217012900/http://www.motorsport.com/indycar/news/irl-preliminary-charlotte-crash-details-outlined|archivedate=2014-02-17|dead-url=no}}</ref> |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Jeffrey|Patton|nolink=1}}|USA}} |- |nowrap| {{flagathlete|{{sortname|Randy|Pyatte|nolink=1}}|USA}} |}

revision.text:
'''Max Freedom Long''' (October 26, 1890 – September 23, 1971) was an American novelist and [[New Age]] author.<ref>Chai, Makana Risser, "Huna, Max Freedom Long, and the Idealization of William Brigham," ''The Hawaiian Journal of History,'' Vol. 45 (2011) p. 101</ref>
==Early life and career== Max Freedom Long was born on October 26, 1890, in [[Sterling, Colorado]] to Toby Albert Long and his wife Jessie Diffendaffer.<ref>{{cite book |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Passport Applications Filed at U.S. Territories and Possessions, 1907-1925: Volume 8|url= |location= Honolulu, HI|publisher= Department of State|page= 2525|date= 1924|isbn=}}</ref> At the time of the 1910 census he was working as a photographer in his hometown, and was living with his grandfather's household with his parents.<ref>{{cite census | url = https://archive.org/stream/13thcensus1910po0122unit#page/n691/mode/2up| title = Thirteenth Census of the United States| year = 1910| location = Sterling, Logan County, CO| roll = | page = 159 | line = 5| enumdist = 245| filmnum = 0112| nafilm = | accessdate = 23 May 2016}}</ref> He attended [[History of the University of California, Los Angeles|Los Angeles State Normal School]] from September 1914 to June 1916, and graduated with an Associate of Arts (two-year) degree in General Education.<ref name="Chai, p. 102">Chai, p. 102</ref> After graduating, he worked briefly as an auto-mechanic in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite book |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= U.S., World War I Draft Registration Cards,|url= |location= Los Angeles, California |publisher= National Archives and Record Administration|page= |date= 1917|isbn=}}</ref>
In 1917, Long moved to the island of [[Hawaii]] to teach in elementary schools around the big island.<ref name="Chai, p. 102">Chai, p. 102</ref> He moved to Honolulu in 1920 and lived there until 1932, where he worked in and later owned a photography store. In 1920, he married an English woman named Jane Jessie Rae, who was the proprietor of the Hotel Davenport in Honolulu. When he arrived in Hawaii, he claimed that some [[Native Hawaiians]] were practicing what he called [[magic (paranormal)|magic]]. Long wrote that at first he was skeptical of this magic, but later became convinced that it worked.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} He devoted the rest of his life to creating theories about how the Native Hawaiians did what he claimed they did, and teaching those theories through the sale of books and newsletters.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
In the mid-1930s, Long relocated to [[Orange County, California]] and began to focus on writing books inspired by his experiences in Hawaii. He married a second time while in California.
==Invention of Huna==
Long decided to call his compilation of teachings [[Huna (New Age)|Huna]], because one meaning of the word is "hidden secret."<ref>Pukui and Ebert ''Hawaiian Dictionary''(University of Hawaii, 1986)</ref> He wrote that he derived it from the word [[kahuna]], who were priests and master craftsmen who ranked near the top of the social scale.<ref>http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/kona/historyg.htm</ref> Long published a series of books on Huna starting in 1936, and founded an organization called the Huna Fellowship in 1945.
There are no accepted Hawaiian sources - Malo,<ref>David Malo, ''Hawaiian Antiquities'' (Bishop Museum, 1951)</ref> Kamakau,<ref>Samuel Kamakau, ''The People of Old'' (Bishop Museum, 1991)</ref> 'I'i,<ref>John Papa 'I'i, ''Fragments of Hawaiian History'' (Bishop Museum, 1959)</ref> [[Kepelino]]<ref>Martha Beckwith, ''Kepelino's Traditions of Hawaii'' (Bishop Museum, 1932)</ref> - that refer to the word Huna as a tradition of esoteric learning.
Max Freedom Long wrote that he obtained many of his case studies and his ideas about what to look for in kahuna magic from the Director of the [[Bishop Museum]] in Honolulu, [[William Brigham]]. There is no credible evidence that the two men met. Even if they did, Brigham was not an expert on kahunas and did not document in his own writings any of the incidents Long ascribed to him, including walking on hot lava. In his letters and manuscripts, Brigham stated that Hawaiians were "an inferior race," and implied they were lazy. He referred to Queen Lili'uokalani as a "she devil," "squaw," and "nigger."<ref>Chai, Makana Risser. "Huna, Max Freedom Long, and the Idealization of William Brigham," ''The Hawaiian Journal of History,'' Vol. 45 (2011) pp. 101-121</ref>
Native Hawaiian scholar Charles Kenn, a [[Living Treasure of Hawai'i]] recognized in the Hawaiian community as a ''kahuna'' and expert in Hawaiian history and traditions,<ref>{{cite book | last = Stone| first = Scott S.C.| authorlink = | title = ''Living Treasures of Hawaii 25th Anniversary of the Selections of Outstanding Persons as Honored by The Honpa Honwanji Mission of Hawai'i'' | publisher = Island Heritage| year = 2000| location = Honolulu| pages = 24| url = | doi = | id = | isbn =}}</ref> was friendly with Max Freedom Long but said, "While this Huna study is an interesting study, … it is not, and never was Hawaiian." <ref name="Lee 1999 56">{{cite book | last = Lee| first = Pali Jae| authorlink = | title = ''Ho`opono''| publisher = Night Rainbow Publishing| year = 1999| location = Honolulu | pages = 56| url = | doi = | id = | oclc =43454305}}</ref>
Hawaiian author Pali Jae Lee, a research librarian at the Bishop Museum, conducted extensive research on Max Freedom Long and Huna. She concluded, based on her interviews with Hawaiian elders, "Huna is not Hawaiian." Lee cites Theodore Kelsey, a [[Living Treasure of Hawai'i]] renowned for his work as a Hawaiian translator who wrote a letter to Long in 1936 (now in the Hawai'i State Archives) criticizing his use of the terms "unihipili" and "aumakua."<ref name="Lee 1999 56"/><ref>{{cite book | last = Lee| first = Pali Jae| authorlink = | title = ''Ho`opono - Revised Edition: The Hawaiian Way to Put Things Back in Balance''| publisher = IM Publishing| year = 2007| location = Mountain View, HI| pages = 89–93| url = | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-9677253-7-6}}</ref>
Professor Lisa Kahaleole Hall writes that Huna "bears absolutely no resemblance to any Hawaiian worldview or spiritual practice" and calls it part of the "New Age spiritual industry."<ref>"'Hawaiian at Heart' and Other Fictions," The Contemporary Pacific, Volume 17, Number 2, 404-413, © 2005 by University of Hawai'i Press http://scholarspace.manoa.hawaii.edu/bitstream/handle/10125/13881/v17n2-404-413-dialogue2.pdf?sequence=1 </ref> Huna books have been called "examples of [[cultural appropriation]]."<ref name="Chai, p. 102"/>
==Later life== Max Freedom Long stopped issuing bulletins in late 1970 due to poor health. He died at his home in [[Vista, California]] on September 23, 1971 from a self-inflicted shotgun wound to his head. He had been suffering from a bone cancer for a few years at that time, and was in constant pain in his final months.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.maxfreedomlong.com/articles/max-freedom-long-died/ |title= MAX FREEDOM LONG DIED SEPT. 23, 1971|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2009 |website= Maxfreedomlong.com|publisher= |access-date= 23 May 2016|quote=}}</ref> He was a believer in [[voluntary euthanasia]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.maxfreedomlong.com/articles/remembering-max-freedom-long/ |title= REMEMBERING MAX FREEDOM LONG (1971)|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2009 |website= Maxfreedomlong.com|publisher= |access-date= 23 May 2016|quote=}}</ref>
==Max Freedom Long Library and Museum== Prior to his death, Long's papers and library became part of the Max Freedom Long Library and Museum at the Huna Research Center at [[Fort Worth, Texas]]. It was established by a student named Dolly Ware, who inherited Long's library. After Dolly Ware's death in 2012, parts of it were sold to antiquarian book dealers. Other parts of the collection became the possession of E. Otha Wingo, who was a direct successor of Long's Huna tradition. Parts of the collection of the original Library and Museum have since been reconstituted at [[Valdosta State University]]'s Archives and Special Collections as part of their New Age Movements, Occultism, and Spiritualism Research Library. The remaining pieces are being sought by the curator of the collection Guy Frost of Valdosta State University's [[Odum Library]].
==Works by Max Freedom Long==
===Huna related works=== * ''Discovering the Ancient Magic, 1936'' * [http://www.holybooks.com/wp-content/uploads/The-Secret-Science-Behind-Miracles.pdf ''The Secret Science Behind Miracles, 1948 (ISBN 0875160476)''] * [http://www.maxfreedomlong.com/huna-bulletins/ ''Huna Bulletins, 1948-1971''] * ''Mana or Vital Force, 1949'' * [http://www.holybooks.com/wp-content/uploads/The-Secret-Science-Behind-Miracles.pdf ''The Secret Behind Miracles, 1953''] ({{ISBN|0875160468}})'' * ''Growing into Light, 1955 ({{ISBN|0875160433}})'' * ''Self-Suggestion and The New Huna Theory of Mesmerism and Hypnosis, 1958'' * ''Psychometric Analysis, 1959'' * ''Huna Code in Religions, 1965 ({{ISBN|0875164951}})'' * ''Short Talks on Huna, 1978 ({{ISBN|0910764026}})'' * ''Recovering the Ancient Magic, 1978 ({{ISBN|0910764018}})'' (originally published 1936) * ''What Jesus Taught in Secret, 1983 ({{ISBN|0875165109}})'' * ''Tarot Card Symbology, 1983 ({{ISBN|0910764077}})''
===Hawaiin Detective Komako Novels=== * ''Murder Between Dark and Dark, 1939'' * ''The Lava Flow Murders, 1940'' * ''Death Goes Native, 1941''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.maxfreedomlong.com/ Official Website] * [http://archives.valdosta.edu/archon/?p=collections/controlcard&id=3765 Max Freedom Long Library and Museum] - Description of the collection held at Valdosta State University's Archives and Special Collections * [http://archives.valdosta.edu/archon/?p=collections/classifications&id=511 New Age Movements, Occultism, and Spiritualism Research Library] - Collection held at Valdosta State University's Archives and Special Collections
===Hawaiian traditions===
*Jensen & Jensen, ''Daughters of Haumea'' (Pueo Press, 2005) *June Gutmanis, ''Kahuna La'au Lapa'au: Hawaiian Herbal Medicine'' (Island Heritage, 1976) *E. S. Craighill Handy, ''Polynesian Religion'' (Kraus Reprint, 1971) *Pali Jae Lee and Koko Willis, ''Tales From the Night Rainbow'' *Makana Risser Chai, ''Na Mo'olelo Lomilomi: Traditions of Hawaiian Massage & Healing'' (Bishop Museum, 2005)
{{New Age Movement}} {{Authority control}}

revision.comment: /* In the United States */Cleaned up references.
revision.text:
{{Criminal law}} '''Mayhem''' is a [[common law]] [[criminal offense]] consisting of the intentional [[maiming]] of another person.
Under the law of [[England and Wales]] and other common law jurisdictions, it originally consisted of the intentional and wanton removal of a body part that would handicap a person's ability to defend themself in [[combat]]. Under the strict common law definition, initially this required damage to an eye or a limb, while cutting off an ear or a nose was deemed not sufficiently disabling. Later the meaning of the crime expanded to encompass any mutilation, disfigurement, or crippling act done using any instrument.
==In England==
===History of definitions=== {{update|type=section|date=August 2011}}<!-- See talk page, section "Abolition in England and Wales" --> In England and Wales, it has fallen into disuse. In 1992 [[Law Commission (England and Wales)|the Law Commission]] recommended that it be abolished,<ref>The Law Commission, Consultation Paper No.122, Offences Against the Person and General Principles, Appendix A, Draft Criminal Law Bill, clause 31(1)(a)(iii) at page 90 of the report [http://www.bailii.org/ew/other/EWLC/1992/c122.html]</ref> and in 1998 the [[Home Office]] proposed to abolish it, in the course of codifying the law relating to [[offences against the person]].<ref>The Home Office. 1998. Violence: Reforming the Offences Against the Person Act 1861. {{cite web |url=http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/documents/cons-1998-violence-reforming-law/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227012915/http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/documents/cons-1998-violence-reforming-law/ |archivedate=2009-02-27 |df= }} Draft Offences Against the Person Bill, clause 23</ref>
===''Fetter v. Beale''=== The most significant change in common-law mayhem doctrine came in 1697, when the King's Bench decided ''Fetter v. Beale'', 91 Eng. Rep. 1122. There, the plaintiff recovered in a battery action against a defendant. Shortly thereafter, "part of his skull by reason of the said battery came out of his head", and the plaintiff brought a subsequent action under mayhem. Though ''Fetter'' is also known as an early example of [[res judicata]], it is most significant for expanding the ambit of mayhem to include "loss of the skull".
==The modern doctrine== In modern times, the offense of mayhem has been superseded in many [[jurisdiction]]s by statutorily defined offenses such as [[aggravated battery]].
==In the United States== Modern statutes in the U.S. define mayhem as disabling or disfiguring, such as rendering useless a member of another person's arms or legs.<ref>E.g. [https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=PEN&sectionNum=203. Cal. Pen. Code Sec. 203]</ref> The injury must be permanent, not just a temporary loss. Some courts will hold even a minor battery as mayhem if the injury is not minor. Mayhem in the U.S. is a [[felony]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Dix |first=George E. |year=2010 |title=Gilbert Law Summaries on Criminal Law |publisher=Thomson/West |isbn=978-0-314-19430-5 |pages=220–221}}</ref>
==Etymology== Both the noun "mayhem" and the verb "[[:wiktionary:maim|maim]]" come from [[Old French]] via [[Anglo-Norman language|Anglo-Norman]]. The word is first attested in various [[Romance languages]] in the 13th century, but its ultimate origin is unclear.<ref>[[Oxford English Dictionary]], Third edition, June 2000; online version June 2011</ref> For one hypothesis about its origin, see [[wiktionary:mayhem|the Wiktionary entry for this word]].
==Other uses== Mayhem can describe a person going on a [[Killing spree|rampage]]. Popular misunderstanding of the common [[journalese]] expression "[[rioting]] and mayhem" caused the common usual modern use of "mayhem" to mean "havoc and disorder", often with humorous overtones.
==References== {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *[[Edward Coke]], [[Institutes of the Laws of England]], Part 3, Chapter 53 (p. 118) (1797 ed.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=_Ik0AAAAIAAJ&printsec=titlepage#PRA2-PA53,M1] (from [[Google Book Search|Google Books]]). *[[Edward Hyde East]], Treatise of Pleas of the Crown, Volume 1, Chapter 7 (pp. 392 – 403) (1806 ed.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=uG40AAAAIAAJ&printsec=titlepage#PPA392,M1] (from [[Google Book Search|Google Books]]). * [[William Hawkins (serjeant-at-law)|William Hawkins]], [[Hawkins' Treatise of Pleas of the Crown|Treatise of Pleas of the Crown]], Book 1, Part 1, Chapter 15, Sections 1 - 12 (pp. 107 – 109) (1824 ed.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=vZc0AAAAIAAJ&printsec=titlepage#PPA107,M1] (from [[Google Book Search|Google Books]]). * John C. Klotter and Terry D. Edwards, ''Criminal Law, fifth edition'' (Anderson Publishing: Cincinnati, Ohio, 1998). {{ISBN|0-87084-527-6}}. *Barbara Allen Babcok, Toni M. Massaro, and Norman W. Spaulding, ''Civil Procedure: Cases and Problems'' (Aspen Publishers: New York, NY 2006). {{ISBN|0-7355-5620-2}}.
[[Category:Offences against the person]] [[Category:Violent crime]] [[Category:Amputations]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox cave | name = Nutty Putty Cave | other_name = | photo = | photo_width = | photo_caption = | location = | coords = {{coord|40|05|51|N|112|02|13|W|type:landmark_region:US-UT|display=inline,title}} | depth = | length = | survey = | survey_format = | discovery = 1960 (Dale Green) | geology = Chert | entrance_count = 1 | entrance_list = | difficulty = Slippery | hazards =Slippery and Tight | access = Closed (since 2009) }}
'''Nutty Putty Cave''' is a [[hydrothermal]] [[cave]] located west of [[Utah Lake]] in [[Utah County, Utah|Utah County]], [[Utah]], [[United States]].
The cave, first explored in 1960 by Dale Green, is currently owned by the Utah School and Institutional Trust Lands Administration,<ref>[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705347362/Man-trapped-in-Utah-Countyaposs-Nutty-Putty-cave-dies.html?pg=3 "Man trapped in Utah County's Nutty Putty cave dies", ''The Deseret News'',26 Nov 2009]</ref> and managed by the Utah Timpanogos Grotto.
In the recent past this cave has had four rescues of cavers and [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scouts]], who became stuck inside the cave's tight twists, turns, and crawls.<ref>[http://www.nuttyputtycave.com/history.html#Timeline NuttyPuttyCave Timeline]</ref>
In 2006, an effort was put forth to study and severely limit the number of visitors allowed inside the cave. It was estimated the cave was receiving over 5,000 visitors per year, with many visitors often entering the cave late at night and failing to take proper safety precautions. The cave’s popularity had caused excessive smoothing of the rock inside the cave to the point it was predicted a fatality would occur in one of the cave's more prominent features, a 45-degree room called "The Big Slide". On May 24, 2006, a [[cave gate|gate]] was installed, and the cave was temporarily closed. In early 2009, proper management was established and an application process was developed to ensure safety precautions were being met. On May 18, 2009 the cave was reopened to the public.<ref>[http://www.nuttyputtycave.com/access.html NuttyPuttyCave Access Presentation Page]</ref>
On November 24, 2009, John Edward Jones died after being trapped in the cave for 28 hours.<ref name=csmonitor>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/1128/p02s07-usgn.html|title= Nutty Putty Cave to be closed for good after trapped caver's death|author= Farrell, Michael B. | date= 2009-11-27 | work = The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate = March 15, 2010}}</ref> Rescuers concluded that it would be too dangerous to attempt to retrieve his body; the landowner and Jones' family came to an agreement that the cave should be permanently closed with the body sealed inside.<ref name=csmonitor /> A film about the tragedy called ''[[The Last Descent]]'' was released on September 16, 2016.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.nuttyputtycave.com/ The Nutty Putty Cave official website] * [http://www.climb-utah.com/WM/Maps/NuttyPuttyCaveMap.pdf Map of Nutty Putty Cave; Climb-Utah.com]
[[Category:Caves of Utah]] [[Category:Landforms of Utah County, Utah]] [[Category:Unusual deaths]] [[Category:Caving incidents]]

page.title: ORB survey of Iraq War casualties

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP;add/change/refine category; MOS fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
On Friday, 14 September 2007, '''ORB International''', an independent polling agency located in London, published '''estimates of the total war casualties in Iraq''' since the [[Iraq War|US-led invasion of Iraq in 2003]].[http://www.zcommunications.org/more-than-1-000-000-iraqis-murdered-since-2003-invasion-by-orb "More than 1,000,000 Iraqis murdered"]. September 2007. Opinion Research Business. At over 1.2 million deaths (1,220,580), this estimate is the highest number published so far. From the poll margin of error of +/-2.5% ORB calculated a range of 733,158 to 1,446,063 deaths. The ORB estimate was performed by a random survey of 1,720 adults aged 18+, out of which 1,499 responded, in fifteen of the eighteen governorates within Iraq, between August 12 and August 19, 2007.[http://www.commondreams.org/archive/2007/09/14/3839/ "Poll: Civilian Death Toll in Iraq May Top 1 Million"]. By Tina Susman. 14 September 2007. ''[[Los Angeles Times]].''[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/world/story/0,,2170237,00.html "Greenspan Admits Iraq was About Oil, As Deaths Put at 1.2 Million"]. By Peter Beaumont and Joanna Walters. 16 September 2007. ''[[The Observer|The Observer (UK)]].'' In comparison, the [[Lancet surveys of Iraq War casualties|2006 Lancet survey]] suggested almost half this number (654,965 deaths) through the end of June 2006. The Lancet authors calculated a range of 392,979 to 942,636 deaths. On 28 January 2008, ORB published an update based on additional work carried out in rural areas of Iraq. Some 600 additional interviews were undertaken September 20 to 24, 2007. As a result of this the death estimate was revised to 1,033,000 with a given range of 946,000 to 1,120,000.[http://www.opinion.co.uk/Newsroom_details.aspx?NewsId=120 Update on Iraqi Casualty Data] by Opinion Research Business, January 2008. Info in PDF and DOC form is linked on the bottom of the page.[http://www.opinion.co.uk/Documents/Revised%20Casulaty%20Data%20-%20Press%20release.doc Revised casualty analysis. New analysis ‘confirms’ 1 million+ Iraq casualties] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219212651/http://www.opinion.co.uk/Documents/Revised%20Casulaty%20Data%20-%20Press%20release.doc |date=February 19, 2009 }}. Jan. 28, 2008. Opinion Research Business. [http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=3657ce88-7cfa-457a-9aec-f4f827f20cac Word Viewer for .doc files]. As well as estimating the number of deaths the ORB poll also showed that despite the violence only 26% of Iraqis preferred life under Saddam Hussein's regime, while 49% said that they preferred life under the current political system.http://www.opinion.co.uk/Newsroom_details.aspx?NewsId=67 This ORB estimate has been criticised as exaggerated and ill-founded in [[peer reviewed]] literature.[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228654909_Conflict_Deaths_in_Iraq_A_Methodological_Critique_of_the_ORB_Survey_Estimate "Conflict Deaths in Iraq: A Methodological Critique of the ORB Survey Estimate"] By Michael Spagat and Josh Dougherty == Survey question and results == Participants of the ORB survey were asked the following question:
How many members of your household, if any, have died as a result of the conflict in Iraq since 2003 (ie as a result of violence rather than a natural death such as old age)? Please note that I mean those who were actually living under your roof.
The revised results were {|class="wikitable" border=1 |- ! Number of deaths
in household ! Percent
of responders |- |None |72% |- |One |14% |- |Two |3% |- |Three |1% |- |Four or more |"figure more than zero but less than 0.5%" |- |Don't know |2% |- |No answer |8% |} == Causes of death == ORB reported that "48% died from a gunshot wound, 20% from the impact of a car bomb, 9% from aerial bombardment, 6% as a result of an accident and 6% from another blast/ordnance." == Methodology == From the September 14, 2007 ORB press release concerning the first set of interviews:
* Results are based on face-to-face interviews amongst a nationally representative sample of 1,720 adults aged 18+ throughout Iraq (1,499 agreed to answer the question on household deaths) * The standard margin of error on the sample who answered (1,499) is +2.5% * The methodology uses multi-stage random probability sampling and covers fifteen of the eighteen governorates within Iraq. For security reasons Karbala and Al Anbar were not included. Irbil was excluded as the authorities refused the field team a permit.
Their pollster was Dr. Munqeth Daghir, founding director of IIACSS.[http://www.research-live.com/features/of-course-i-was-scared-but-i-really-believe-that-i-am-doing-the-right-thing/2001599.article "Of course I was scared. But I really believe that I am doing the right thing"]. Article about ORB pollster Dr. Munqeth Daghir. Jan. 2006. ''Research'' (magazine). (See also: [http://www.opinion.co.uk/Documents/Polling%20in%20Iraq.pdf PDF article with photos]). ORB reports: "IIACSS (Independent Institute for Administration and Civil Society Studies) is a polling/ research company established in Iraq in 2003 and which has a network of interviewers covering all regions of the country. Further information about IIACSS and its founding director Dr. Munqith Dagher can be found within the relevant news article in the Newsroom section of ORB's website." ORB is a member of the [[British Polling Council]]. == Estimated range of deaths == The 2005 census reported 4,050,597 households. From this ORB calculated 1,220,580 deaths since the 2003 invasion. From the poll margin of error of 2.5% ORB came up with a range of 733,158 to 1,446,063 deaths. == January 2008 update: 1,033,000 deaths == Opinion Research Business published an update to the survey on 28 January 2008, based on additional work carried out in rural areas of Iraq. Some 600 additional interviews were undertaken and as a result of this the death estimate was revised to 1,033,000 with a given range of 946,000 to 1,120,000. == Criticism == The ORB poll estimate has come under criticism in a [[peer reviewed]] paper entitled "Conflict Deaths in Iraq: A Methodological Critique of the ORB Survey Estimate", published in the journal [[Survey Research Methods]]. This paper "describes in detail how the ORB poll is riddled with critical inconsistencies and methodological shortcomings", and concludes that the ORB poll is "too flawed, exaggerated and ill-founded to contribute to discussion of the human costs of the Iraq war".[http://w4.ub.uni-konstanz.de/srm/article/viewArticle/2373 "Conflict Deaths in Iraq: A Methodological Critique of the ORB Survey Estimate"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719105821/http://w4.ub.uni-konstanz.de/srm/article/viewArticle/2373 |date=July 19, 2011 }} By Michael Spagat and Josh Dougherty[http://www.rhul.ac.uk/aboutus/newsandevents/news/newsarticles/Studyrevealsfundamentalflawsto2007estimateofonemillionIraqiskilled.aspx "Study reveals fundamental flaws to 2007 estimate of one million Iraqis killed"] Royal Holloway University of London Epidemiologist Francisco Checci recently{{when|date=June 2014}} echoed these conclusions in a BBC interview, stating that he thinks the ORB estimate was "too high" and "implausible". Checci, like the paper above, says that a "major weakness" of the poll was a failure to adequately distinguish between households and extended family.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/news/2010/08/100827_iraq_deaths_nh_sl.shtml "Counting bodies: how many people were killed in the Iraq war?"] BBC World Service The [[Iraq Body Count project]] also rejected what they called the "hugely exaggerated death toll figures" of ORB, citing the [[Survey Research Methods]] paper,which Josh Dougherty of IBC co-wrote. IBC concluded that, "The pressing need is for more truth rooted in real experience, not the manipulation of numbers disconnected from reality."[http://www.iraqbodycount.org/analysis/beyond/exaggerated-orb/ "Exaggerated claims, substandard research, and a disservice to truth"] By Iraq Body Count [[John Rentoul]], a columnist for ''[[The Independent]]'' newspaper, has asserted that the ORB estimate "exaggerate[s] the toll by a factor of as much as 10" and that "the ORB estimate has rarely been treated as credible by responsible media organisations, but it is still widely repeated by cranks and the ignorant."http://blogs.independent.co.uk/2010/06/13/iraq-death-tolls-yet-again/ ==See also== *[[Casualties of the Iraq War]]. An overview of many casualty estimates. *[[Iraq War]]. Infobox there has the most up-to-date casualty figures. *[[Lancet surveys of Iraq War casualties]] *[[Iraq Family Health Survey]] ==References== [[Category:Iraq War casualties]] [[Category:Death in Iraq]] [[Category:Surveys]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{Infobox GAA player | code= Hurling | sport = Hurling | image = | name = Pat Buckley | irish = Pádraig Ó Buachalla | fullname = Patrick Buckley | height = | nickname = | county = Cork | province = Munster | club = [[Aghabullogue GAA|Aghabullogue]] | clposition = Forward | clubs = Aghabullogue | clyears = 1880s-1890s | clapps(points) = | clcounty = 1 | clprovince= | clallireland = | counties = Cork | icposition = Forward | icyears = 1892-1894 | icapps(points) = 4 (?-?) | icprovince = 2 | icallireland = 2 | nhl = | allstars = | clupdate = | icupdate = | birth_place=[[Aghabullogue]], [[County Cork]] }} '''Pat Buckley''' was an [[Irish people|Irish]] sportsperson. He played hurling with his local club [[Aghabullogue GAA|Aghabullogue]] and was a member of the [[Cork GAA|Cork]] senior inter-county team from 1890 until 1892. Buckley, together with his team-mate [[Dan Drew]], became the first players to win two All-Ireland winners' medals on the field of play.<ref>{{cite book| first=Jim| last=Cronin| title=A Rebel Hundred: Cork's 100 All-Ireland Titles| publisher=| year=1998| id= | page=8}}</ref>
==Playing career== ===Club=== Buckley played his hurling with his local club in [[Aghabullogue GAA|Aghabullogue]] and enjoyed some success. He won a [[Cork Senior Hurling Championship|county senior championship]] title in 1890 following a 7-3 to 1-1 defeat of [[Aghada GAA|Aghada]]. It remains Aghabullogue's only county final victory.
===Inter-county=== Buckley first came to prominence on the inter-county scene with [[Cork GAA|Cork]] as part of the Aghabullogue selection in 1890. That year he lined out in his first provincial decider with [[Kerry GAA|Kerry]] providing the opposition. The game was far from exciting, however, at full-time Cork were the champions by 2-0 to 0-1.<ref name="Munster GAA">{{cite web|url=http://munster.gaa.ie/teams/seniorhurling.html |title=Senior Hurling - Munster Final Winning Teams (1887-2007) |publisher=[[Munster GAA]] |date= |accessdate=2009-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719154803/http://munster.gaa.ie/teams/seniorhurling.html |archivedate=July 19, 2008 }}</ref> It was Buckley's first [[Munster Senior Hurling Championship|Munster]] title. Cork's next game was an All-Ireland final meeting with [[Wexford GAA|Wexford]]. The game was a controversial one and was marred by ill-tempered behaviour. A Cork player had his toe broken by one of his Wexford counterparts. Cork captain, [[Dan Lane]], led his men off the field in protest. At the time Cork were trailing by 2-2 to 1-6, however, the [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]]'s Central Council later backed Cork and Buckley collected an [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship]] title.<ref name="Cork Hurling Profile">{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/Cork/Profile.aspx|title=Cork Hurling Profile|publisher=www.hoganstand.com|date=|accessdate=2009-03-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216074254/http://hoganstand.com/Cork/Profile.aspx|archivedate=2009-02-16|df=}}</ref>
Buckley was dropped from the Cork team again in 1891, however, he was back in 1892. That year he lined out in his second provincial decider with All-Ireland champions Kerry providing the opposition once again. An exciting game developed, however, at full-time Cork were the champions by 5-3 to 2-5.<ref name="Munster GAA"/> It was Buckley's second Munster title. Cork's next game was an All-Ireland final meeting with [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]]. The game was a controversial one as referee [[Dan Fraher]] changed his mind after initially awarding a goal to Cork. He eventually decided that the [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]]'s Central Council should decide the matter. Dublin, however, had walked off the field and, because of this, Cork were awarded the title. It was Buckley's second All-Ireland title.<ref name="Cork Hurling Profile"/>
==Honours== ===Aghabullogue=== *'''[[Cork Senior Hurling Championship]]''': 1 **'''Winner (1):''' 1890
===Cork=== *'''[[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship]]''': 2 **'''Winner (2):''' 1890, 1892 *'''[[Munster Senior Hurling Championship]]''': 2 **'''Winner (2):''' 1890, 1892

revision.comment: recategorized per [[Wikipedia:Categories_for_discussion/Log/2018_October_28#Category:Neural_networks]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} [[File:Place Cell Spiking Activity Example.png|thumb|right|alt=A drawing of a rat at one end of a curving path. Along the path, there are numerous dots in clusters, with each cluster a different color.|Spatial firing patterns of 8 place cells recorded from the [[Hippocampus proper|hippocampal CA1]] layer of a rat's brain. Dots indicate positions (place fields) where [[action potential]]s were recorded as the rat moved back and forth along a track, with color indicating which neuron emitted that action potential.]]
'''Phase precession''' is a [[neurophysiology|neurophysiological]] process in which the firing of [[action potential]]s by individual [[neuron]]s is timed in relation to the [[phase (waves)|phase]] of [[neural oscillation]]s in the surrounding cells. In [[place cell]]s, a type of neuron found in the [[hippocampus|hippocampal]] region of the [[brain]], phase [[wikt:precession|precession]] is believed to play a major role in the [[neural coding]] of information. [[John O'Keefe (neuroscientist)|John O'Keefe]], who later shared the 2014 [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] for his discovery that place cells help form a "map" of the body's position in space, co-discovered phase precession with Michael Recce in 1993.<ref name="OKeefe1993">{{cite journal | vauthors = O'Keefe J, Recce ML | title = Phase relationship between hippocampal place units and the EEG theta rhythm | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/hipo.450030307/abstract;jsessionid=D7DEB7FEC2C5F67890498798FC9414DE.f01t01?system | journal = Hippocampus | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 317–30 | date = July 1993 | pmid = 8353611 | doi = 10.1002/hipo.450030307 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180129182136/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/hipo.450030307/abstract;jsessionid=D7DEB7FEC2C5F67890498798FC9414DE.f01t01?system | archivedate = 29 January 2018 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2014/okeefe-bio.html|title=The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2014: John O'Keefe – Biograhpical|website=Nobelprize.org|accessdate=27 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929044010/https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2014/okeefe-bio.html|archivedate=29 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Place cells== {{main|Place cell}} [[Pyramidal cell]]s in the hippocampus called place cells play a significant role in self-location during movement over short distances.<ref name="Moser 69–77">{{cite journal | vauthors = Moser EI, Kropff E, Moser MB | title = Place cells, grid cells, and the brain's spatial representation system | url = http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev.neuro.31.061307.090723 | journal = Annual Review of Neuroscience | volume = 31 | pages = 69–89 | date = 19 February 2008 | pmid = 18284371 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.neuro.31.061307.090723 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161124223905/http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev.neuro.31.061307.090723 | archivedate = 24 November 2016 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> As a rat moves along a path, individual place cells fire action potentials at an increased rate at particular positions along the path, termed "place fields". Each place cell's maximum firing rate{{snd}}with action potentials occurring in rapid [[Bursting|bursts]]{{snd}}occurs at the position encoded by that cell; and that cell fires only occasionally when the animal is at other locations.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bures J, Fenton AA, Kaminsky Y, Zinyuk L | title = Place cells and place navigation | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 94 | issue = 1 | pages = 343–50 | date = January 1997 | pmid = 8990211 | pmc = 19339 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.94.1.343 }}</ref> Within a relatively small path, the same cells are [[Hippocampal replay|repeatedly activated]] as the animal returns to the same position.
[[File:Place field spikes cropped.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A jagged line with upward-downward deflections. A rectangular box surrounds one deflection.|Action potentials (one in the box) recorded from a single place cell during a [[Bursting|burst]] of activity]]
Although simple [[rate coding]] (the coding of information based on whether neurons fire more rapidly or more slowly) resulting from these changes in firing rates may account for some of the neural coding of position, there is also a prominent role for the [[Phase response curve|timing of the action potentials]] of a single place cell, relative to the firing of nearby cells in the [[neural ensemble|local population]].<ref name=Dual>{{cite journal | vauthors = O'Keefe J, Burgess N | title = Dual phase and rate coding in hippocampal place cells: theoretical significance and relationship to entorhinal grid cells | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/hipo.20115/abstract?system | journal = Hippocampus | volume = 15 | issue = 7 | pages = 853–66 | date = 6 September 2005 | pmid = 16145693 | doi = 10.1002/hipo.20115 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180129175126/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/hipo.20115/abstract?system | archivedate = 29 January 2018 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=Computations>{{cite journal | vauthors = Burgess N, O'Keefe J | title = Neuronal computations underlying the firing of place cells and their role in navigation | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1098-1063(1996)6:6%3C749::AID-HIPO16%3E3.0.CO;2-0/abstract?system | journal = Hippocampus | volume = 6 | issue = 6 | pages = 749–62 | date = 1996 | pmid = 9034860 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1098-1063(1996)6:6<749::AID-HIPO16>3.0.CO;2-0 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180129175123/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1098-1063(1996)6:6%3C749::AID-HIPO16%3E3.0.CO;2-0/abstract?system | archivedate = 29 January 2018 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> As the larger population of cells fire occasionally when the rat is outside of the cells' individual place fields, the firing patterns are organized to occur synchronously, forming [[waveform|wavelike]] [[voltage]] oscillations. These oscillations are measurable in [[local field potential]]s and [[electroencephalography]] (EEG). In the [[Hippocampus proper|CA1 region]] of the hippocampus, where the place cells are located, these firing patterns give rise to [[theta wave]]s.<ref name=Theta>{{cite journal | vauthors = Skaggs WE, McNaughton BL, Wilson MA, Barnes CA | title = Theta phase precession in hippocampal neuronal populations and the compression of temporal sequences | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1098-1063(1996)6:2%3C149::AID-HIPO6%3E3.0.CO;2-K/abstract?system | journal = Hippocampus | volume = 6 | issue = 2 | pages = 149–72 | date = 1996 | pmid = 8797016 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1098-1063(1996)6:2<149::AID-HIPO6>3.0.CO;2-K | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180129180632/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1098-1063(1996)6:2%3C149::AID-HIPO6%3E3.0.CO;2-K/abstract?system | archivedate = 29 January 2018 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> Theta oscillations have classically been described in rats, but evidence is emerging that they also occur in humans.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bohbot VD, Copara MS, Gotman J, Ekstrom AD | title = Low-frequency theta oscillations in the human hippocampus during real-world and virtual navigation | journal = Nature Communications | volume = 8 | pages = 14415 | date = February 2017 | pmid = 28195129 | pmc = 5316881 | doi = 10.1038/ncomms14415 }}</ref>
[[File:eeg theta.svg|thumb|right|350px|alt=A wavelike curvy line, with time in seconds labeled at the bottom|An [[Electroencephalography|EEG]] [[theta wave]]]]
In 1993, O'Keefe and Recce discovered a relationship between the theta wave and the firing patterns of individual place cells.<ref name="OKeefe1993"/> Although the occasional action potentials of cells when rats were outside of the place fields occurred in phase with (at the peaks of) the theta waves, the bursts of more rapid spikes elicited when the rats reached the place fields were out of synchrony with the oscillation. As a rat approached the place field, the corresponding place cell would fire slightly in advance of the theta wave peak. As the rat moved closer and closer, each successive action potential occurred earlier and earlier within the wave cycle. At the center of the place field, when the cell would fire at its maximal rate, the firing had been advanced sufficiently to be anti-phase to the theta potential (at the bottom, rather than at the peak, of the theta waveform). Then, as the rat continued to move on past the place field and the cell firing slowed, the action potentials continued to occur progressively earlier relative to the theta wave, until they again became synchronous with the wave, aligned now with one wave peak earlier than before. O'Keefe and Recce termed this advancement relative to the wave phase "phase precession". Subsequent studies showed that each time a rat entered a completely different area and the place fields would be [[Phase resetting in neurons|remapped]], place cells would again become phase-locked to the theta rhythm.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bose A, Recce M | title = Phase precession and phase-locking of hippocampal pyramidal cells | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/hipo.1038/abstract?system | journal = Hippocampus | volume = 11 | issue = 3 | pages = 204–15 | date = 19 June 2001 | pmid = 11769305 | doi = 10.1002/hipo.1038 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180129175120/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/hipo.1038/abstract?system | archivedate = 29 January 2018 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> It is now widely accepted that the anti-phase cell firing that results from phase precession is an important component of information coding about place.<ref name="Moser 69–77"/><ref name=Dual/><ref name=Computations/><ref name=Theta/><ref name=Buzsaki>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ldz58irprjYC&pg=PA308&|title=Rhythms of the Brain|first=György|last=Buzsáki|name-list-format=vanc|date=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0195301064|pages=308–26|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180226103105/https://books.google.com/books?id=ldz58irprjYC&pg=PA308&|archivedate=26 February 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Other systems== There have been conflicting theories of [[Theta wave#Mechanisms|how neurons in and around the hippocampus give rise to theta waves]] and consequently give rise to phase precession. As these mechanisms became better understood, the existence of phase precession was increasingly accepted by researchers.<ref name=Buzsaki/> This, in turn, gave rise to the question of whether phase precession could be observed in any other regions of the brain, with other kinds of [[Neural circuit|cell circuits]], or whether phase precession was a peculiar property of hippocampal tissue.<ref name=Buzsaki/> The finding that theta wave phase precession is also a property of [[grid cell]]s in the [[entorhinal cortex]] demonstrated that the phenomenon exists in other parts of the brain that also mediate information about movement.<ref>{{cite journal | url = https://www.nature.com/articles/nature06957 | vauthors = Hafting T, Fyhn M, Bonnevie T, Moser MB, Moser EI | title = Hippocampus-independent phase precession in entorhinal grid cells | journal = Nature | volume = 453 | issue = 7199 | pages = 1248–52 | date = June 2008 | pmid = 18480753 | doi = 10.1038/nature06957 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180130000010/http://www.nature.com/articles/nature06957 | archivedate = 30 January 2018 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
Theta wave phase precession in the hippocampus also plays a role in some brain functions that are unrelated to spatial location. When rats were trained to jump up to the rim of a box, place cells displayed phase precession much as they do during movement along a path, but a subset of the place cells showed phase precession that was related to initiating the jump, independently of spatial location, and not related to the position during the jump.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lenck-Santini PP, Fenton AA, Muller RU | title = Discharge properties of hippocampal neurons during performance of a jump avoidance task | journal = The Journal of Neuroscience | volume = 28 | issue = 27 | pages = 6773–86 | date = July 2008 | pmid = 18596153 | pmc = 2636898 | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5329-07.2008 }}</ref>
