Ltd. Financial Results Briefing for Fiscal Year Ended March 2010|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/pdf/2010/100507e.pdf|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=2017-12-03}}, 650,000+ copies sold from ''[[Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Gates to Infinity|Gates to Infinity]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2013-01-28-pokemon-tops-2012-software-charts-in-japan|title=Pokemon tops 2012 software chart in Japan|last=Handrahan|first=Matthew|date=28 January 2013|work=[[GamesIndustry]]|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=21 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/pikmin-3-us-sales-reach-115000-units-6414410|title=Pikmin 3 US sales reach 115,000 units|last=Makuch|first=Eddie|date=12 September 2013|work=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=4 October 2013}} and 1.22 million copies sold from [[Pokémon Super Mystery Dungeon|''Super Mystery Dungeon'']].{{Cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/pdf/2016/160427_4e.pdf|title=Nintendo Co., Ltd. Earning Release for Fiscal Year Ended March 2016 Supplementary Information|last=|first=|date=Apr 28, 2016|website=[[Nintendo]]|publisher=Nintendo Co., Ltd|access-date=November 11, 2016}} == References == {{reflist}} {{Pokémon}} {{Pokémon spin-offs}} {{Mystery Dungeon series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pokemon Mystery Dungeon}} [[Category:Nintendo franchises]] [[Category:Pokémon RPGs|Mystery Dungeon]] [[Category:Role-playing video games]] [[Category:Tactical role-playing video games]] [[Category:Video game franchises]] [[Category:2005 video games]] [[Category:Video games with alternate versions]] [[Category:Roguelike video games]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue''}} {{Infobox video game | title = ''Pokémon Red''
''Pokémon Blue'' | image = File:Pokémon box art - Red Version.png | caption = North American box art for ''Pokémon Red Version'', depicting the Pokémon [[Charizard]]. The ''Pokémon Blue Version'' box art depicts the Pokémon [[Blastoise]] (not pictured). The ''Pokémon Green Version'' box art depicts the Pokémon [[Venusaur]] (not pictured). | developer = [[Game Freak]] | publisher = [[Nintendo]] | series = ''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]'' | platforms = [[Game Boy]] | released = '''''Red and Green'''''{{Video game release|JP|February 27, 1996{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.co.jp/game/other/gb-rg/|title=ポケットモンスター 赤・緑|publisher=[[The Pokémon Company]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/apajapbj/|title=ポケットモンスター赤・緑|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}}}}'''''Blue (Japan)'''''{{Video game release|JP|October 15, 1996{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.co.jp/game/other/gb-blue/|title=ポケットモンスター 青|publisher=[[The Pokémon Company]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/apej/|title=ポケットモンスター青|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}}}}'''''Red and Blue'''''{{Video game release|NA|September 28, 1998{{cite web|title=Game Boy's Pokémon Unleashed on September 28!|url=https://www.nintendo.com/corp/press/100298.html|publisher=Nintendo|accessdate=29 March 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990501171038/http://www.nintendo.com/corp/press/100298.html|archivedate=May 1, 1999|location=Redmond, Washington|date=September 28, 1998}}|AUS|October 23, 1998|EU|October 5, 1999{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.com/uk/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-red-version-and-pokemon-blue-version/|title=Pokémon Red Version and Pokémon Blue Version|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}}}} | genre = [[Role-playing video game|Role-playing]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | director = [[Satoshi Tajiri]] | producer = [[Shigeru Miyamoto]]
Takashi Kawaguchi
[[Tsunekazu Ishihara]] | designer = Satoshi Tajiri | artist = [[Ken Sugimori]] | writer = Satoshi Tajiri
Ryosuke Taniguchi
Fumihiro Nonomura
Hiroyuki Jinnai | composer = [[Junichi Masuda]] | italic title=no }} '''''Pokémon Red Version''''' and '''''Blue Version'''''{{efn|Originally released in Japan as {{Nihongo|'''''Pokémon Red Version''''' and '''''Green Version'''''|ポケットモンスター 赤・緑|Poketto Monsutā Aka Midori|lit. ''Pocket Monsters: Red & Green''}}}} are [[role-playing video game]]s developed by [[Game Freak]] and published by [[Nintendo]] for the [[Game Boy]]. They are the first installments of the ''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]'' series. They were first released in Japan in 1996 as ''Red'' and ''Green''. "Blue" was released later in the year as a special edition. They were later released as ''Red'' and ''Blue'' in North America, Europe, and Australia over the following three years. ''[[Pokémon Yellow]]'', a special edition version, was released roughly a year later. ''Red'' and ''Green'' have subsequently been [[video game remake|remade]] for the [[Game Boy Advance]] as [[Pokémon FireRed and LeafGreen|''Pokémon FireRed'' and ''LeafGreen'']], released in 2004. The player controls the protagonist from an [[top-down perspective|overhead perspective]] and navigates him throughout the fictional region of Kanto in a quest to master [[Pokémon battle|Pokémon battling]]. The goal of the games is to become the champion of the Indigo League by defeating the eight [[Gym Leaders]] and then the top four Pokémon trainers in the land, the [[Elite Four]]. Another objective is to complete the [[Pokédex]], an in-game encyclopedia, by obtaining the 150 available Pokémon. ''Red'' and ''Blue'' utilize the [[Game Link Cable]], which connects two games together and allows Pokémon to be traded or battled between games. Both titles are independent of each other but feature the same plot,{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/159/159846p1.html|title=Pokemon Red Version Review|publisher=IGN|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=1999-06-23|accessdate=2008-06-26}} and while they can be played separately, it is necessary for players to trade among both games in order to obtain all of the first 150 Pokémon. ''Red'' and ''Blue'' were well-received with critics praising the multiplayer options, especially the concept of trading. They received an aggregated score of 89% on [[GameRankings]] and are considered among [[Lists of games considered the best|the greatest games ever made]], perennially ranked on top game lists including at least four years on [[IGN]]'s Top 100 Games of All Time. The games' releases marked the beginning of what would become a multibillion-dollar franchise, jointly selling hundreds of millions of copies worldwide. In 2009 they appeared in the ''[[Guinness Book of World Records]]'' under "Best selling RPG on the Game Boy" and "Best selling RPG of all time". The games were re-released on the [[Nintendo 3DS]] [[Virtual Console]] service as a commemoration of the franchise's 20th anniversary in 2016. ==Gameplay== {{Main|Gameplay of Pokémon}} [[File:Bulbasaur pokemon red.png|thumb|left|The player's level 5 [[Bulbasaur]] (bottom) engaged in a battle with the rival's level 5 [[Charmander]] (top)]] ''Red'' and ''Blue'' are played in a [[Virtual camera system#Third-person view|third-person view]], [[overhead perspective]] and consist of three basic screens: an [[overworld]], in which the player navigates the main character;{{cite book|author=[[Game Freak]]|title=Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=1997-12-09|page=8}} a side-view battle screen;{{cite book|author=[[Game Freak]]|title=Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=1998-09-30|page=17}} and a menu interface, in which the player configures his or her Pokémon, items, or gameplay settings.{{cite book|author=[[Game Freak]]|title=Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=1998-09-30|page=10}} The player can use his or her Pokémon to battle other Pokémon. When the player [[random encounter|encounters a wild Pokémon]] or is challenged by a trainer, the screen switches to a [[turn-based]] battle screen that displays the engaged Pokémon. During a battle, the player may select a [[Pokémon moves|maneuver]] for his or her Pokémon to fight using one of four [[Gameplay of Pokémon|moves]], use an item, switch his or her active Pokémon, or attempt to flee. Pokémon have [[health (gaming)|hit points]] (HP); when a Pokémon's HP is reduced to zero, it faints and can no longer battle until it is revived. Once an enemy Pokémon faints, the player's Pokémon involved in the battle receive a certain number of [[experience point]]s (EXP). After accumulating enough EXP, a Pokémon will [[Levels up|level up]]. A Pokémon's level controls its physical properties, such as the [[Pokémon statistics|battle statistics]] acquired, and the [[Pokémon moves|moves]] it has learned. At certain levels, the Pokémon may also evolve. These evolutions affect the statistics and the levels at which new moves are learned (higher levels of evolution gain more statistics per level, although they may not learn new moves as early, if at all, compared with the lower levels of evolution).{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gameboy/rpg/pokemonblue/review.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206184212/http://www.gamespot.com/gameboy/rpg/pokemonblue/review.html|archivedate=2010-02-06|title=GameSpot review|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|first=Peter|last=Bartholow|date=2000-01-28|accessdate=2008-06-26|deadurl=yes|df=}} [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Catching Pokémon|Catching]] Pokémon is another essential element of the gameplay. While battling with a wild Pokémon, the player may throw a [[Poké Ball]] at it. If the Pokémon is successfully caught, it will come under the player's ownership. Factors in the success rate of capture include the HP of the target Pokémon and the type of Poké Ball used: the lower the target's HP and the stronger the Poké Ball, the higher the success rate of capture.{{cite book|author=[[Game Freak]]|title=Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=1998-09-30|page=21}} The ultimate goal of the games is to complete the entries in the [[Pokédex]], a comprehensive Pokémon encyclopedia, by capturing, [[Pokémon evolution|evolving]], and trading to obtain all 151 creatures.{{cite book |author = [[Game Freak]] |title = Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual |publisher = [[Nintendo]] |date =1998-09-30 |page=7}} ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'' allow players to trade Pokémon between two [[ROM cartridge|cartridges]] via a [[Game Link Cable]].{{cite book |author = [[Game Freak]] |title = Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual |publisher = [[Nintendo]] |date =1998-09-30 |page=36}} This method of trading must be done to fully complete the Pokédex since certain Pokémon will only evolve upon being traded and each of the two games have version-exclusive Pokémon. The Link Cable also makes it possible to battle another player's Pokémon team. When playing ''Red'' or ''Blue'' on a [[Game Boy Advance]] or [[Game Boy Advance SP|SP]], the standard GBA/SP link cable will not work; players must use the Nintendo Universal Game Link Cable instead.{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.com.au/gbc/faqs/index.php|title=nintendo.com.au – GBC – Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=Nintendo|accessdate=2008-10-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222212654/http://www.nintendo.com.au/gbc/faqs/index.php|archivedate=2007-12-22}} Moreover, the English versions of the games are incompatible with their Japanese counterparts, and such trades will corrupt the save files, as the games use different languages and therefore character sets.{{cite web|title=Game Boy Game Pak Troubleshooting – Specific Games|url=https://www.nintendo.com/consumer/systems/gameboy/trouble_specificgame.jsp#missingno|quote=MissingNO is a programming quirk, and not a real part of the game|publisher=Nintendo of America Inc.|accessdate=2009-06-09}} As well as trading with each other and ''Pokémon Yellow'', ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'' can trade Pokémon with the second generation of Pokémon games: [[Pokémon Gold and Silver|''Pokémon Gold'', ''Silver'', and ''Crystal'']]. However, there are limitations: the games cannot link together if one player's party contains Pokémon or moves introduced in the second generation games.{{cite web|url=http://guidesarchive.ign.com/guides/12865/trading.html|title=Pokemon Gold and Silver Strategy Guide: Trading|publisher=IGN|accessdate=2008-06-27}} Also, using the [[Transfer Pak]] for the [[Nintendo 64]], data such as Pokémon and items from ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'' can be used in the Nintendo 64 games ''[[Pokémon Stadium]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/n64/puzzle/pokemonstadium/review.html?om_act=convert&om_clk=gssummary&tag=summary;read-review|title=Pokemon Stadium for Nintendo 64 Review|publisher=GameSpot|first=Jeff|last=Gerstmann|date=2000-02-29|accessdate=2008-09-16}} and ''[[Pokémon Stadium 2]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/n64/strategy/pokemonstadium2/review.html?om_act=convert&om_clk=gssummary&tag=summary%3Bread-review&page=2|title=Pokemon Stadium 2 for Nintendo 64 Review|publisher=GameSpot|first=Gerald|last=Villoria|page=2|date=2001-03-26|accessdate=2008-09-16}} ''Red'' and ''Blue'' are incompatible with the ''Pokémon'' games of the later "Advanced Generation" for the [[Game Boy Advance]] or [[GameCube]].{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/389/389660p2.html|title=IGN: Pokemon Ruby Version Review|publisher=IGN|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=2003-03-17|accessdate=2008-10-25}} ==Plot== [[File:Kanto-Full-Map.jpg|thumb|left|''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'' take place in the Kanto region, based on Japan's real [[Kantō region]].]] ===Setting=== ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'' take place in the region of [[Pokémon universe#Kanto|Kanto]]. This is one distinct region shown in later games, with different geographical habitats for the 151 existing Pokémon species, along with human-populated towns and cities, and Routes connecting locations with one another. Some areas are only accessible once the player learns a special ability or gains a special item.{{cite book|author=[[Game Freak]]|title=Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=1998-09-30|page=20}} Areas in which the player can catch Pokémon range from caves to the sea, where the kinds of Pokémon available to catch varies. For example, [[Tentacool (Pokémon)|Tentacool]] can only be caught either through fishing or when the player is in a body of water, while [[Zubat (Pokémon)|Zubat]] can only be caught in a cave. ===Story=== The player begins in their hometown of Pallet Town. After venturing alone into the tall grass, the player is stopped by [[Professor Oak]], a famous Pokémon researcher. Professor Oak explains to the player that wild Pokémon may be living there, and encountering them alone can be very dangerous.{{cite book|author=[[Game Freak]]|title=Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=1998-09-30|page=2}} He takes the player to his laboratory where the player meets Oak's grandson, a rival aspiring [[Pokémon Trainer]]. The player and the rival are both instructed to select a [[starter Pokémon]] for their travels out of [[Bulbasaur]], [[Squirtle]], and [[Charmander]].{{cite book|author=[[Game Freak]]|title=Pokémon Red and Blue, Instruction manual|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=1998-09-30|page=3}} Oak's Grandson will always choose the Pokémon which is stronger against the player's starting Pokémon. He will then challenge the player to a Pokémon battle with their newly obtained Pokémon and will continue to battle the player at certain points throughout the games.{{cite web|url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/16708/page_113.html|title=Guides: Pokemon: Blue and Red|publisher=IGN|author=IGN Staff|page=113|accessdate=2008-10-24}} While visiting the region's cities, the player will encounter special establishments called Gyms. Inside these buildings are [[Pokémon game mechanics#Pokémon Gyms|Gym Leaders]], each of whom the player must defeat in a Pokémon battle to obtain a total of eight Gym Badges. Once the badges are acquired, the player is given permission to enter the Indigo League, which consists of the best Pokémon trainers in the region. There the player will battle the [[Elite Four]] and finally the new [[List of Pokémon characters#Regional Champions|Champion]]: the player's rival.{{cite web|url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/16708/page_67.html|title=Guides: Pokemon: Blue and Red|page=67|publisher=IGN|author=IGN Staff|accessdate=2008-06-27}} Also, throughout the game, the player will have to battle against the forces of [[Team Rocket]], a criminal organization that abuses Pokémon. They devise numerous plans for stealing rare Pokémon, which the player must foil.{{cite web|url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/16708/page_99.html|title=Guides: Pokemon: Blue and Red|page=99|publisher=IGN|author=IGN Staff|accessdate=2009-02-04}}{{cite web|url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/16708/page_165.html|title=Guides: Pokemon: Blue and Red|page=165|publisher=IGN|author=IGN Staff|accessdate=2009-02-04}} ==Development== [[File: The Story of Satoshi Tajiri.webm|thumb|An animated history of how Satoshi Tajiri came to conceive ''Pokémon'']] The concept of the ''Pokémon'' saga stems from the hobby of [[insect collecting]], a popular [[pastime]] which [[game designer]] [[Satoshi Tajiri]] enjoyed as a child.{{cite news|first=Amadeo|last=Plaza|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070126085524/http://www.ampednews.com/features/182/2 |archivedate=January 26, 2007 |url=http://igo.ampednews.com/features/182/2/|title=A Salute to Japanese Game Designers|publisher=Amped IGO|page=2|date=2006-02-06|accessdate=2006-06-25}} While growing up, however, he observed more urbanization taking place in the town where he lived and as a result, the insect population declined. Tajiri noticed that kids now played in their homes instead of outside and he came up with the idea of a video game, containing creatures that resembled insects, called Pokémon. He thought kids could relate with the Pokémon by individually naming them, and then controlling them to represent fear or anger as a good way of relieving stress. However, Pokémon never bleed nor die in battle, only faint – this was a very touchy subject to Tajiri, as he did not want to further fill the gaming world with "pointless violence".{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/asia/magazine/99/1122/pokemon6.fullinterview2.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112054158/http://www.time.com/time/asia/magazine/99/1122/pokemon6.fullinterview2.html|archivedate=2007-11-12|title=The Ultimate Game Freak|publisher=TIME Asia|first=Time|last=Larimer|page=2|date=1999-11-22|accessdate=2008-09-16}} When the [[Game Boy]] was released, Tajiri thought the system was perfect for his idea, especially because of the [[Game Link Cable|link cable]], which he envisioned would allow players to trade Pokémon with each other. This concept of trading information was new to the video gaming industry because previously connection cables were only being used for competition.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/asia/magazine/99/1122/pokemon6.fullinterview1.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212005118/http://www.time.com/time/asia/magazine/99/1122/pokemon6.fullinterview1.html|archivedate=2007-12-12|title=The Ultimate Game Freak|publisher=TIME Asia|first=Time|last=Larimer|page=1|date=1999-11-22|accessdate=2008-09-16}} "I imagined a chunk of information being transferred by connecting two Game Boys with special cables, and I went wow, that's really going to be something!" said Tajiri. Tajiri was also influenced by [[Square (company)|Square]]'s Game Boy game ''[[The Final Fantasy Legend]]'', noting in an interview that the game gave him the idea that more than just action games could be developed for the handheld.{{cite web |language=Japanese |url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/nom/0007/taidan1/page02.html |title=Pokémon interview |publisher=[[Nintendo]] |accessdate=2009-06-06}} The main characters were named after Tajiri himself as [[Red (Pokémon character)|Satoshi]], who is described as Tajiri in his youth, and his long-time friend, role model, mentor, and fellow Nintendo developer; [[Shigeru Miyamoto]] as [[Blue (Pokémon character)|Shigeru]].{{cite web|url=http://top100.ign.com/2007/ign_top_game_37.html|title=IGN's Top 100 Games 2007 | 37 Pokemon Blue Version|publisher=IGN|accessdate=2008-09-15|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/67qcIxX2d?url=http://top100.ign.com/2007/ign_top_game_37.html|archive-date=2012-05-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} [[Ken Sugimori]], an artist and longtime friend of Tajiri, headed the development of drawings and designs of the Pokémon, working with a team of fewer than ten people who conceived the various designs for all 151 Pokémon. Sugimori, in turn, finalized each design, drawing the Pokémon from various angles in order to assist Game Freak's graphics department in properly rendering the creature.{{cite web |url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ds/interview/irbj/vol1/index2.html |title=2. 一新されたポケモンの世界 |page=2 |work=Nintendo.com |publisher=[[Nintendo]] |accessdate=2010-09-10 |author=Staff |language=Japanese}}{{cite book|first=Chris|last=Kohler|year=2004|title=[[Power-Up: How Japanese Video Games Gave the World an Extra Life]]|edition=1st|publisher=[[BradyGames]]|isbn=0-7440-0424-1|pages= 237–250}} Music for the game was composed by [[Junichi Masuda]], who utilized the four sound channels of the Game Boy to create both the melodies and the sound effects and Pokémon "cries" heard upon encountering them. He noted the game's opening theme, titled "Monster", was produced with the image of battle scenes in mind, using [[white noise]] to sound like marching music and imitate a [[snare drum]].{{cite web |url=http://www.gamefreak.co.jp/blog/dir_english/?p=143 |title=HIDDEN POWER of Masuda: No. 125 |author=Masuda, Junichi |authorlink=Junichi Masuda |publisher=[[Game Freak]] |date=2009-02-28 |accessdate=2009-06-09}} Originally called ''Capsule Monsters'', the game's title went through several transitions due to trademark difficulties, becoming ''CapuMon'' and ''KapuMon'' before eventually settling upon ''Pocket Monsters''.{{cite web |url=http://allabout.co.jp/gm/gc/215584/ |script-title=ja:写真で綴るレベルＸ～完全保存版！ |publisher=AllAbout.co.jp |language=Japanese |accessdate=2010-05-21 |date=2004-02-18 |author=Staff}}{{cite book |script-title=ja:ゲームフリーク 遊びの世界標準を塗り替えるクリエイティブ集団 |language=Japanese |author=Tomisawa, Akihito |isbn=4-8401-0118-3 |date=August 2000}} Tajiri always thought that [[Nintendo]] would reject his game, as the company did not really understand the concept at first. However, the games turned out to be a complete success, something Tajiri and Nintendo never expected, especially because of the declining popularity of the Game Boy. Upon hearing of the ''Pokémon'' concept, Miyamoto suggested creating multiple cartridges with different Pokémon in each, noting it would assist the trading aspect.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/3979/the_art_of_balance_pokmons_.php |title= The Art of Balance: Pokémon's Masuda on Complexity and Simplicity |author=Nutt, Christian |date=2009-04-03 |accessdate=2009-06-09 |publisher=[[Gamasutra]]}} In Japan, ''Pocket Monsters: Red'' and ''Green'' were the first versions released, having been completed by October 1995 and officially released on February 27, 1996. They sold rapidly, due in part to Nintendo's idea of producing the two versions of the game instead of a single title, prompting consumers to buy both. Several months later, the ''[[#Pocket Monsters: Blue|Blue]]'' version was released in Japan as a mail-order-only special edition,{{cite journal|author=Staff|title=What's the Deal with Pokémon?|journal=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]|page=216|date=November 1999 |issue=124}} featuring updated in-game artwork and new dialogue.{{cite journal |journal=[[Tips & Tricks]] |publisher=[[Larry Flynt Publications]] |date=December 1999 |page=111 |title=Pokémon Report |last=Chen |first=Charlotte}} To create more hype and challenge to the games, Tajiri revealed an extra Pokémon called [[Mew (Pokémon)|Mew]] hidden within the games, which he believed "created a lot of rumors and myths about the game" and "kept the interest alive". The creature was originally added by [[Shigeki Morimoto]] as an internal prank and wasn't supposed to be exposed to consumers.{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/news/iwata/iwata_asks_-_pokmon_heartgold_version__soulsilver_version_16288_16289.html#top|title=Iwata Asks – Pokémon HeartGold Version & SoulSilver Version|publisher=[[Nintendo]].com|accessdate=2012-10-16}} It was not until later that Nintendo decided to distribute Mew through a Nintendo promotional event. However, in 2003 a glitch became widely known and could be exploited so anyone could obtain the elusive Pokémon.{{cite web|url=http://ds.ign.com/articles/933/933126p1.html|title=IGN: Pokemon Report: OMG Hacks |publisher=IGN |first=Jack |last=DeVries |date=2008-11-24 |accessdate=2009-02-16}} During the North American [[Game localization|localization]] of ''Pokémon'', a small team led by Hiro Nakamura went through the individual Pokémon, renaming them for western audiences based on their appearance and characteristics after approval from Nintendo Co. Ltd. In addition, during this process, Nintendo trademarked the 151 Pokémon names in order to ensure they would be unique to the franchise.{{cite journal |author=Staff |title=What's the Deal with Pokémon? |journal=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |page=172 |date=November 1999 |issue=124}} During the translation process, it became apparent that simply altering the games' text from Japanese to English was impossible; the games had to be entirely reprogrammed from scratch due to the fragile state of their [[source code]], a side effect of the unusually lengthy development time. Therefore, the games were based on the more modern Japanese version of ''Blue''; modeling its programming and artwork, but keeping the same distribution of Pokémon found in the Japanese ''Red'' and ''Green'' cartridges, respectively. As the finished ''Red'' and ''Blue'' versions were being prepared for release, Nintendo allegedly spent over 50 million dollars to promote the games, fearing the series would not be appealing to American children.{{cite book|last=Tobin|first=Joseph Jay|year=2004|title=Pikachu's Global Adventure: The Rise and Fall of Pokémon|publisher=Duke University Press|page=66|isbn=0-8223-3287-6}} The western localization team warned that the "cute monsters" may not be accepted by American audiences, and instead recommended they be redesigned and "beefed-up". Then-president of Nintendo [[Hiroshi Yamauchi]] refused and instead viewed the games' possible reception in America as a challenge to face.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5260140/pokemon-could-have-been-muscular-monsters|title=Pokemon Could Have Been Muscular Monsters|publisher=Kotaku|first=Brian|last=Ashcraft|date=2009-05-18|accessdate=2009-06-26}} Despite these setbacks, the reprogrammed ''Red'' and ''Blue'' versions with their original creature designs were eventually released in North America over two and a half years after ''Red'' and ''Green'' debuted in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/16708/page_62.html|title=Guides: Pokemon: Blue and Red|page=62|publisher=IGN|author=IGN Staff|accessdate=2008-10-24}} The games were received extremely well by the foreign audiences and Pokémon went on to become a lucrative franchise in America. ===Music=== The music was composed by [[Junichi Masuda]]{{cite web|url=http://vgmdb.net/album/141|title=GB Pokémon Complete Sound CD|publisher=VGMdb|accessdate=2015-07-07}} on a [[Commodore International|Commodore]] [[Amiga]] computer, which only features [[PCM]] sample playback, and converted to the Game Boy with a program he had written.http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2014/05/13/pokemon_2700_s-music-master-the-man-behind-the-catchiest-songs.aspx ==Reception and legacy== {{Video game reviews | GR = 88% (Red){{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/gameboy/367023-pokemon-red/index.html|title=Pokemon Red Reviews|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=2015-06-22}} | Allgame = {{Rating|4.5|5}} (Blue){{cite web |last=McCaul |first=Scott|title= Pokemon Blue Version -Review |publisher=[[Allgame]] |accessdate=December 4, 2012 |url=http://allgame.com/game.php?id=14222&tab=review|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141114211617/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=14222&tab=review|archivedate=November 14, 2014}} | EGM = 8.5/10 (Red) | Fam = 29/40{{cite web |url=http://www.famitsu.com/cominy/?m=pc&a=page_h_title&title_id=10914 |language=Japanese |work=Famitsu |publisher=Enterbrain, Inc. |title=ポケットモンスター 赤/緑 まとめ [ゲームボーイ]}} | GSpot = 8.8/10 (Blue) | IGN = 10/10 (Red) | NP = 7.2/10{{Cite journal |journal=[[Nintendo Power]] |volume=113 |date=October 1998 |title=Now Playing: Pokémon |page=112}} }} ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'' set the precedent for what has become a blockbuster, multibillion-dollar franchise.{{cite news|title=Pokemon Franchise Approaches 150 Million Games Sold |url=http://www2.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/10-04-2005/0004159206&EDATE= |agency=PR Newswire |publisher=Nintendo |date=4 October 2005 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426072034/http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104 |archivedate=April 26, 2007 }} By 1997, ''Red'', ''Green'', and ''Blue'' combined had sold 10.4 million copies in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://hdl.handle.net/10022/AC:P:28|title=Pokemania: Secrets Behind the International Phenomenon|publisher=Columbia Business School|author=Safier, Joshua | author2=Nakaya, Sumie|date=2000-02-07|accessdate=2011-08-05}} By the end of its run, it had sold a total combined sale of 9.85 million in the United States{{cite web|url= http://www.the-magicbox.com/Chart-USPlatinum.shtml|title=US Platinum Videogame Chart|publisher=The Magic Box|accessdate=2008-08-03| date=2007-12-27}} while an additional 3.56 million have been sold in the United Kingdom.{{citation needed|reason=Number not found anywhere except in references to Wikipedia. Number implies rest of Europe had ≈0 sales|date=June 2015}} The games worldwide sales have reached over 31 million copies sold.{{Cite news|url=https://247wallst.com/special-report/2018/01/30/most-popular-video-games-of-all-time/10/|title=50 Most Popular Video Games of All Time|work=247wallst.com|access-date=2018-05-21|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/264530/all-time-best-selling-console-games-worldwide/|title=All-time best selling console games worldwide 2018 {{!}} Statistic|website=Statista|language=en|access-date=2018-05-21}} In 2009, [[IGN]] referred to ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'' as the "[[List of best-selling Game Boy video games|Best selling RPG on the Game Boy]]" and "[[List of best-selling video games|Best selling RPG of all time]]".{{cite web|url=http://ds.ign.com/articles/946/946074p1.html|title=IGN: Pokemon Report: World Records Edition|publisher=IGN|first=Jack|last=DeVries|date=2009-01-16|accessdate=2009-02-16}} The games received mostly positive reviews from critics, holding an aggregate score of 87.86% on [[GameRankings]]. Special praise was given to its [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] features: the ability to trade and battle Pokémon with one another. Craig Harris of [[IGN]] gave the games a "masterful" 10 out of 10, noting that: "Even if you finish the quest, you still might not have all the Pokémon in the game. The challenge to catch 'em all is truly the game's biggest draw". He also commented on the popularity of the game, especially among children, describing it as a "craze". [[GameSpot]]'s Peter Bartholow, who gave the games a "great" 8.8 out of 10, cited the graphics and audio as somewhat primitive but stated that these were the games' only drawbacks. He praised the titles' replay value due to their customization and variety, and commented upon their universal appeal: "Under its cuddly exterior, Pokémon is a serious and unique RPG with lots of depth and excellent multiplayer extensions. As an RPG, the game is accessible enough for newcomers to the genre to enjoy, but it will entertain hard-core fans as well. It's easily one of the best Game Boy games to date". The success of these games has been attributed to their innovative gaming experience rather than audiovisual effects. Papers published by the [[Columbia Business School]] indicate both American and Japanese children prefer the actual gameplay of a game over special audio or visual effects. In ''Pokémon'' games, the lack of these artificial effects has actually been said to promote the child's imagination and creativity. "With all the talk of [[game engine]]s and [[texture mapping]] and so on, there is something refreshing about this superlative gameplay which makes you ignore the cutesy 8-bit graphics" commented ''[[The Guardian]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/1999/sep/30/onlinesupplement15?commentpage=1|title=Monsters to the rescue|publisher=The Guardian|author=Bodle, Andy and Greg Howson|date=1999-09-30|accessdate=2009-01-15}} The video gaming website [[1UP.com]] composed a list of the "Top 5 'Late to the Party' Games" showing selected titles that "prove a gaming platform's untapped potential" and were one of the last games released for their respective [[video game console|console]]. ''Red'' and ''Blue'' were ranked first and called Nintendo's "secret weapon" when the games were brought out for the Game Boy in the late 1990s.{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/do/feature?cId=3167655|title=Best Games to Come Out Late in a System's Life|publisher=1UP|author=1UP Staff|accessdate=2008-09-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226064448/http://www.1up.com/do/feature?cId=3167655|archivedate=2009-02-26|df=}} ''[[Nintendo Power]]'' listed the ''Red'' and ''Blue'' versions together as the third best video game for the [[Game Boy]]/[[Game Boy Color]], stating that something about the game kept them playing until they caught every Pokémon.{{cite journal |date=August 2008 |title=Nintendo Power – The 20th Anniversary Issue! |volume=231 |series= [[Nintendo Power]] |issue=231 |page=72 |pages= |publisher=[[Future US]] |location=[[San Francisco, California]] |type=Magazine}} ''[[Game Informer]]''{{'}}s Ben Reeves called them (along with ''Pokémon Yellow'', ''Gold'', ''Silver'', and ''Crystal'') the second best Game Boy games and stated that it had more depth than it appeared.{{cite web |title=The 25 Best Game Boy Games Of All Time |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2011/06/24/the-25-best-game-boy-games-of-all-time.aspx |work=[[Game Informer]] |last=Reeves |first=Ben |date=2011-06-24 |accessdate=2013-12-06}} ''[[Official Nintendo Magazine]]'' named the games one of the best Nintendo games of all time, placing 52nd on their list of the top 100 games.{{cite web|url=http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/article.php?id=7258|title=Feature: 100 Best Nintendo Games|publisher=''[[Official Nintendo Magazine]]''|first=Tom|last=East|date=2009-03-02|accessdate=2009-03-18}} ''Red'' and ''Blue'' made number 72 on ''IGN's Top 100 Games of All Time'' in 2003, in which the reviewers noted that the pair of games "started a revolution" and praised the deep game design and complex strategy, as well the option to trade between other games.{{cite web|url=http://top100.ign.com/2003/71-80.html|author=Staff|title=The Top 100: 71–80|publisher=IGN|date=2003-04-30|accessdate=2008-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090910004823/http://top100.ign.com/2003/71-80.html|archive-date=2009-09-10|dead-url=yes|df=}} Two years later, it climbed the ranks to number 70 in the updated list, with the games' legacy again noted to have inspired multiple video game sequels, movies, television shows, and other merchandise, strongly rooting it in [[popular culture]].{{cite web|url=http://top100.ign.com/2005/061-070.html|title=IGN's Top 100 Games 061-070|publisher=IGN|accessdate=2008-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009135800/http://top100.ign.com/2005/061-070.html|archive-date=2014-10-09|dead-url=yes|df=}} In 2007 ''Red'' and ''Blue'' were ranked at number 37 on the list, and the reviewers remarked at the games' longevity: {{quote|For everything that has come in the decade since, it all started right here with ''Pokémon Red''/''Blue''''. Its unique blend of exploration, training, battling and trading created a game that was far more in-depth than it first appeared and one that actually forced the player to socialize with others in order to truly experience all that it had to offer. The game is long, engrossing and sparkles with that intangible addictiveness that only the best titles are able to capture. Say what you will about the game, but few gaming franchises can claim to be this popular ten years after they first hit store shelves.}} The games are widely credited with starting and helping pave the way for the successful multibillion-dollar series. Five years after ''Red'' and ''Blue'''s initial release, Nintendo celebrated its "Pokémoniversary". George Harrison, the senior vice president of marketing and corporate communications of Nintendo of America, stated that "those precious gems [''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue''] have evolved into ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire''. The release of ''Pokémon Pinball'' kicks off a line of great new Pokémon adventures that will be introduced in the coming months".{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/435/435984p1.html|title=IGN: Nintendo Celebrates Pokemoniversary|publisher=IGN|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=2003-08-29|accessdate=2008-09-15}} The series has since sold over 300 million games, all accredited to the enormous success of the original ''Red'' and ''Blue'' versions.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/pokemon-game-sales-pass-300-million-units/1100-6455215/|title=Pokemon Game Sales Pass 300 Million Units|last=Makuch|first=Eddie|date=2017-11-27|website=GameSpot|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-21}} On February 12, 2014, an anonymous Australian programmer launched [[Twitch Plays Pokémon|Twitch Plays ''Pokémon'']], a "social experiment" on the video streaming website [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]]. The project was a [[Crowdsourcing|crowdsourced]] attempt to play a modified version of ''Pokémon Red'' by typing commands into the channel's chat log, with an average of 50,000 viewers participating at the same time. The result was compared to "watching a [[Traffic collision|car crash]] in slow motion".{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/twitch-plays-pokmon-the-largest-massively-multiplayer-pokmon-game-is-beautiful-chaos-9133732.html|title=Twitch plays Pokémon: The largest 'massively multiplayer' Pokémon game is beautiful chaos|work=The Independent|accessdate=2015-02-16}} The game was completed on March 1, 2014, boasting 390 hours of multi-user controlled non-stop gameplay.{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-57619740-93/twitch-plays-pokemon-conquers-elite-four-beating-game-after-390-hours/|title=Twitch Plays Pokemon conquers Elite Four, beating game after 390 hours|publisher=CBS Interactive|work=CNET|accessdate=2015-02-16}} ==Other versions== ===''Pokémon Blue'' (Japan)=== {{nihongo4|'''''Pokémon Blue Version'''''|ポケットモンスター 青|Poketto Monsutā Ao|lit. "Pocket Monsters Blue"}} was released in Japan as a mail-order-only special edition to subscribers of ''[[CoroCoro Comic]]'' on October 15, 1996. It was later released to general [[retail]] on October 10, 1999. The game featured updated in-game artwork and new dialogue. Using Blastoise as its mascot, the code, script, and artwork for ''Blue'' was used for the international releases of ''Red'' and ''Green'', which were renamed to ''Red'' and ''Blue''. The Japanese ''Blue'' edition of the game features all but a handful of Pokémon available in ''Red'' and ''Green'', making certain Pokémon exclusive to these original editions. ===''Pokémon Yellow''=== {{main|Pokémon Yellow}} {{nihongo4|'''''Pokémon Yellow Version: Special Pikachu Edition'''''|ポケットモンスター ピカチュウ|Poketto Monsutā Pikachū|lit. "Pocket Monsters Pikachu"}}, or simply '''''Pokémon Yellow Version''''', was a special edition of the ''Red'' and ''Blue'' versions, and was originally released on September 12, 1998, in Japan,{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.co.jp/game/other/gb-pikachu/|title=ポケットモンスター ピカチュウ|publisher=[[The Pokémon Company]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/apsj/|title=ポケットモンスター ピカチュウ|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}} with releases in North America and Europe on October 1, 1999,{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.com/us/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-yellow-special-pikachu-edition/|title=Pokémon™ Yellow Special Pikachu Edition|publisher=[[The Pokémon Company|The Pokémon Company International]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}} and June 16, 2000,{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.com/uk/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-yellow-special-pikachu-edition/|title=Pokémon™ Yellow Special Pikachu Edition|publisher=[[The Pokémon Company|The Pokémon Company International]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}} respectively. The game was designed to resemble the [[Pokémon (anime)|''Pokémon'' anime series]], with the player receiving a [[Pikachu]] as his starter Pokémon, and his rival starting with an Eevee. Some non-player characters resemble those from the anime, including Team Rocket: [[Team Rocket (anime)|Jessie and James]]. ===''Pokémon FireRed'' and ''LeafGreen''=== {{main|Pokémon FireRed and LeafGreen}} {{nihongo4|'''''Pokémon FireRed Version''''' and '''''LeafGreen Version'''''|ポケットモンスター ファイアレッド・リーフグリーン|Poketto Monsutā Faiareddo Rīfugurīn|lit. "Pocket Monsters: FireRed & LeafGreen"}} are [[enhanced remake]]s of ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue''. The new titles were developed by [[Game Freak]] and published by [[Nintendo]] for the [[Game Boy Advance]] and have compatibility with the [[Game Boy Advance Wireless Adapter]], which originally came bundled with the games. However, due to the new variables added to ''LeafGreen'' and ''FireRed'' (such as changing the single, "Special" stat into two separate "Special Attack" and "Special Defense" stats), these titles are not compatible with older versions. ''FireRed'' and ''LeafGreen'' were first released in Japan on January 29, 2004,{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.co.jp/game/gba/fl/|title=ポケットモンスター ファイアレッド・リーフグリーン|publisher=[[The Pokémon Company]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n08/bprj/|title=ポケットモンスター ファイアレッド・リーフグリーン|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}} and released to North America and Europe on September 9{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.com/us/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-firered-version-and-pokemon-leafgreen-version/|title=Pokémon™ FireRed Version and Pokémon™ LeafGreen Version|publisher=[[The Pokémon Company|The Pokémon Company International]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}} and October 1,{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.com/uk/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-firered-version-and-pokemon-leafgreen-version/|title=Pokémon™ FireRed Version and Pokémon™ LeafGreen Version|publisher=[[The Pokémon Company|The Pokémon Company International]]|accessdate=2013-03-13}} respectively. Nearly two years after their original release, Nintendo re-marketed them as ''[[Nintendo Selects|Player's Choice]]'' titles.{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/721/721379p1.html|title=IGN: Player's Choice, Round Two|publisher=IGN|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=2006-07-26|accessdate=2009-09-05}} The games received critical acclaim, obtaining an aggregate score of 81 percent on [[Metacritic]].{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/gba/pokemonfirered?q=Pokemon|title=Pokemon FireRed (gba: 2004): Reviews|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618002929/http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/gba/pokemonfirered?q=Pokemon |archivedate=2008-06-18 |deadurl=yes|accessdate=2009-09-05}} Most critics praised the fact that the games introduced new features while still maintaining the traditional gameplay of the series. Reception of the graphics and audio was more mixed, with some reviewers complaining that they were too simplistic and not much of an improvement over the previous games, [[Pokémon Ruby and Sapphire|''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'']]. ''FireRed'' and ''LeafGreen'' were commercial successes, selling a total of around 12 million copies worldwide.{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/pdf/2008/080425e.pdf#page=6|title=Financial Results Briefing for Fiscal Year Ended March 2008|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=2008-04-25|page=6|format=PDF|accessdate=2009-09-05}} ===Virtual Console=== On November 12, 2015, Nintendo announced during a Nintendo Direct that the original generation of ''Pokémon'' games would be released on the [[Nintendo 3DS]] [[Virtual Console]] service on February 27, 2016, the 20th anniversary of the games' original Japanese release. The games also include a first for the Virtual Console—simulated [[Game Link Cable|Link Cable]] functionality to allow trading and battling between games.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VF3AnGHbG6s|title=Nintendo Direct - 11.12.2015|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=2015-11-12|accessdate=2015-11-14}} Each region received the versions of the game as originally released; as such, ''Green'' is exclusive to Japanese consumers.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XUxgnYVD_-Q|title=Nintendo Direct 2015.5.31 プレゼンテーション映像|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=2015-11-12|accessdate=2015-11-14}} These versions are able to transfer Pokémon to [[Pokémon Sun and Moon|''Pokémon Sun'' and ''Moon'']] via the ''[[List of Pokémon video games#Pokémon Bank|Pokémon Bank]]'' application.{{cite web|last1=Conditt|first1=Jessica|title=Pokemon Sun And Moon Hit The Nintendo 3DS This Holiday|url=https://www.engadget.com/2016/02/26/pokemon-sun-and-moon-hit-the-nintendo-3ds-this-holiday/|website=Engadget|accessdate=26 February 2016}} There is also a special bundle along with the [[Nintendo 2DS]] with each console matching the corresponding color of the game version which was released in Japan, Europe, and Australia on February 27, 2016.{{cite news|last1=Kamen|first1=Matt|title=Pokémon marks 20th birthday with retro 2DS bundles|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/pokemon-2ds-consoles-anniversary-release|accessdate=3 August 2016|date=12 January 2016}} North America received a special New Nintendo 3DS bundle with cover plates of Red and Blue's box art.{{cite news|last1=Farokhmanesh|first1=Megan|title=Pokémon celebrates its 20th anniversary with a New Nintendo 3DS bundle this February|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/1/12/10754140/pokemon-new-nintendo-3ds-red-blue-yellow|accessdate=3 August 2016|work=Polygon|date=12 January 2016}} By March 31, 2016, combined sales of the re-releases reached 1.5 million units with more than half being sold in the American market.{{cite web|publisher=Nintendo|date=April 28, 2016|accessdate=May 1, 2016|title=Financial Results Briefing for Fiscal Year Ended March 2016|page=3|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/en/library/events/160428/03.html}} ===''Pokémon: Let's Go, Pikachu!'' and ''Eevee!''=== {{main|Pokémon: Let's Go, Pikachu! and Let's Go, Eevee!}} ==See also== * ''[[Pokémon Origins]]'' – an [[anime]] television special based on the original games {{Clear}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.pokemon.com/us/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-red-version-and-pokemon-blue-version/ ''Pokémon Red Version and Pokémon Blue Version''] * [https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/apajapbj/index.html ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Green''] {{ja icon}} * [https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/apej/index.html ''Pokémon Blue''] {{ja icon}} {{Portal bar|Nintendo|Pokémon|Video games|1990s}} {{Pokémon}} {{Good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pokemon Red And Blue}} [[Category:1996 video games]] [[Category:Game Boy games]] [[Category:Game Freak games]] [[Category:Interactive Achievement Award winners]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Role-playing video games]] [[Category:Pokémon RPGs|Red And Blue]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games with alternate versions]] [[Category:Virtual Console games for Nintendo 3DS]] [[Category:Virtual pet video games]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/117.220.131.156|117.220.131.156]] ([[User talk:117.220.131.156|talk]]): not adhering to [[WP:MOS|manual of style]] ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.1)
revision.text:
'''Schizocoely''' (adjective forms: '''schizocoelous''' or '''schizocoelic''') is a process by which some animal [[embryonic development|embryos develop]]. [[Animal]]s which develop through schizocoely are known as '''schizocoelomates'''. Schizocoely occurs when a [[coelom]] (body cavity) is formed by splitting the [[mesoderm]]al embryonic tissue.<ref name=moore>{{Cite book | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=bZw-ntFxp-YC&dq=coelom&as_brr=3&source=gbs_navlinks_s | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 9780521857369 | last1 = Moore | first1 = Janet | last2 = Overhill | first2 = Raith | title = An introduction to the invertebrates | date = 2006 }}</ref>
Schizocoelous development is typically attributed to [[protostomes]]:<ref name=moore /> phyla [[Mollusca]], [[Annelida]], and [[Arthropoda]], but some [[deuterostomes]] can exhibit schizocoely as well.{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} <!--'''NOTE TO EXPERT EDITOR: This still doesn't make any sense. Saying it is exclusive is NOT compatible with saying that some deuterostomes can exhibit it. Unless you mean to suggest that "Schizocoelous development" is different from "schizocoely", in which case you need to explain.''' ... Better now?-->
The term refers to the order of organization of cells in the [[gastrula]] leading to development of the [[coelom]]. In these three phyla of organisms, the [[mesoderm]] (the middle [[germ layer]]) forms as a solid mass of migrated cells from the single layer of the gastrula. The new mesoderm then splits, creating the pocket-like cavity of the coelom.
==See also== * [[Embryology]] * [[Enterocoely]] == References == <references />
==External links== * Enterocoelous and schizocoelous conditions - [http://www.utm.edu/departments/cens/biology/rirwin/enteroschizo.htm UTM.edu]
[[Category:Developmental biology]] [[Category:Embryology]]
{{developmental-biology-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Stephen Sewell Foster''' (born '''Sewell Foster''') (November 22, 1792 – December 29, 1868) was a physician and political figure in [[Canada East]].
He was born in [[Oakham, Massachusetts]] in 1792. He studied medicine, was licensed to practice in [[Vermont]] in 1815 and settled in [[Newfane, Vermont|Newfane]] there. In 1822, he moved to Frost Village near [[Waterloo, Quebec|Waterloo]] in [[Lower Canada]] with his family. He was licensed to practice medicine in the province in 1830. He served as surgeon to a militia battalion and was also [[coroner]] for the Bedford District and a justice of the peace in Shefford County. Foster also was a founder and served as administrator for the Shefford Academy in Frost Village. In 1841, he was elected to represent [[Shefford (electoral district)|Shefford]] in the [[Legislative Assembly of the Province of Canada]] and was reelected in 1844. He served as a governor of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Lower Canada from 1847 to 1866. In 1857, he moved to [[Knowlton, Quebec|Knowlton]] where he continued to practice medicine until his death in 1868.
His son [[Asa Belknap Foster|Asa Belknap]] also served as a member of the Legislative Assembly and was named to the Senate of Canada.
==External links== * {{QuebecMNAbio|foster-stephen-sewell-3225}} *{{Cite DCB|4431}}

revision.text:
[[Image:ERAEmerita 138.JPG|thumb|Latin inscription from [[Mérida, Spain]], in the Museo Nacional de Arte Romano (National Museum of Roman Art), reading:
M(arco) Cornelio M(arci) f(ilio) Pap(iria) Pollio / M(arco) Cornelio Urbano / M(arco) Cornelio Celeri / Cornelia M(arci) l(iberta) Iucunda / sic nuncquam Fortuna sinat te nosse dolo[rem] / praeterisse potes quasm pius o iuvenis / sit datus in flammas nosse doloris rit nunc petit i[---] / quisquis ades dicas '''sit tibi terra levis''' h(ic) [---] ]] '''''Sit tibi terra levis''''' (commonly abbreviated as ''S·T·T·L'' or ''S.T.T.L.'' or ''STTL'') is a [[Latin]] inscription used on [[headstone|funerary items]] from [[ancient Roman]] times{{cite book|first=Judson Allen|last=Tolman|title= Dissertation: A study of the sepulchral inscriptions in Buecheler's ''Carmina epigraphica latina''|publisher=University of Chicago press|year=1910|pages=3,6|url=https://archive.org/stream/astudysepulchra00tolmgoog#page/n19/mode/1up}} onwards. The English language translation is approximately "May the earth rest lightly on you" or "May the ground be light to you"; the more literal, word by word, translation, is [[wikt:sit#Latin|''sit'']] "may be", [[wikt:tibi#Latin|''tibi'']] "to you", [[wikt:terra#Latin|''terra'']] "ground, soil", [[wikt:levis#Latin|''levis'']] "light" (in the sense of the opposite of "heavy"). The origin of the phrase can be found in [[Euripides]]' ''[[Alcestis (play)|Alcestis]]''; the phrase in [[Greek language|Greek]] is {{lang|grc|κούφα σοι χθὼν ἐπάνωθε πέσοι}}, ''koupha soi chthon epanothe pesoi''.{{cite book|author=Euripides|title=Alcestis|language=Greek|chapter=Verses: 463-4|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0087%3Acard%3D455}} {{cite book|title=Alcestis|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0088%3Acard%3D455|chapter=Verses: 463-4}}; [[cf.]] {{cite book|title=[[Helen (play)|Helen]]|language=Greek|chapter=Verses: 852-3|chapter-url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Eur.+Hel.+852&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0099}} {{cite book|title=[[Helen (play)|Helen]]|chapter-url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Eur.+Hel.+852&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0100|chapter=Verses: 852-3}} At the [[Perseus Project]].{{cite book|title=Ancient Jewish Epitaphs: An Introductory Survey of a Millennium of Jewish Funerary Epigraphy (300 BCE-700 CE)|author-first=Pieter Willem van der|author-last=Horst|author-link=Pieter Willem van der Horst|page=54|publisher=Kok Pharos Publishing House|place=[[Kampen, Overijssel|Kampen]]|year=1991|ISBN=90-242-3307-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F549XluX9DQC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA54#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Euripides' phrase "underwent all kinds of variations",cf. {{cite book|author=Menander|author-link=Menander|title=The Fragments of Attic Comedy|volume=IIIB|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q8sUAAAAIAAJ&lpg=PA523&pg=PA778#v=onepage&q&f=false|chapter=Fragment 538, Verse 3|editor-first=Edmonds|editor-last=John Maxwell|editor-link=John Maxwell Edmonds|pages=778-9|year=1961|place=[[Leyden]]|publisher=[[E. J. Brill]]|language= Greek, English}} At [[Google Books]].{{refn|group=n|A later [[satirical]] example of this in Greek, is the following [[epigram]] (cf. Martial's ''Epigrammata 9.29.11-12'') by Ammianus Epigrammaticus (1st and/or 2nd century CE):
{{lang|grc|Εἴη σοι κατὰ γῆς κούφη κόνις, οἰκτρὲ Νέαρχε, ὄφρα σε ῥηϊδίως ἐξερύσωσι κύνες.}} ''May the dust lie light on thee when under earth, wretched Nearchus, so that the dogs may easily drag thee out.''{{cite book|title=The Greek anthology |volume=VI|url=https://archive.org/stream/greekanthologyv01patogoog#page/n190/mode/1up|pages=178-9|chapter=Book XI, Epigram 226|year=1918|series=[[Loeb Classical Library]]|others=With an English translation by [[William Roger Paton|W. R. Paton]]}} At the [[Internet Archive]].{{cite book|title=A Commentary on Martial, Epigrams, Book 9|first=Christer|last=Henriksén|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TgPJfgToMpMC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA127#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2012|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=978-019-960631-3|page=127}}{{cite book|title= A Dictionary of Greek and Roman biography and mythology|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0104:alphabetic+letter%3DA:entry+group%3D19:entry%3Dammianus-bio-1|editor-first=William|editor-last=Smith|year=1873|chapter=Ammianus}} At the Perseus Project.}} especially in Latin poets like [[Propertius]], [[Ovid]], [[Martial]] and [[Persius]];[[Persius]], ''Saturae'', I, 37.{{cite book|title=Epigrammata|author=Martial|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0506%3Abook%3D9%3Apoem%3D29|chapter= Book 9, Epigram 29, Verse 11|language=Latin}} cf. {{cite book|title=Epigrammata|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Mart.+5.34&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0506|chapter= Book 5, Epigram 34, Verses 9-10}} {{cite book|title=Epigrammata|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Mart.+6.68&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0506|chapter= Book 6, Epigram 68, Verse 12}} At the Perseus Project.{{cite book|title=[[Amores (Ovid)|Amores]]|author=Ovid|chapter-url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0068%3Atext%3DAm.%3Abook%3D3%3Apoem%3D9|chapter= Book 3, Poem 9, Verse 68|language=Latin}} {{cite book|title=[[Amores (Ovid)|Amores]]|chapter-url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0069%3Atext%3DAm.%3Abook%3D3%3Apoem%3D9|chapter=Book 3, Poem 9, Verse 68}} At the Perseus Project.{{cite book|title=Elegiae|author=Propertius|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0066%3Abook%3D1%3Apoem%3D17|chapter= Book 1, Poem 17, Verse 24|language=Latin}} {{cite book|title=Elegiae|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0067%3Abook%3D1%3Apoem%3D17|chapter=Book 1, Poem 17, Verse 24}} At the Perseus Project.cf. {{cite book|title=Troades|last=Seneca|author-link=Seneca the Younger|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Sen.+Tro.+602&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2007.01.0011|language=Latin|chapter=Verse 602}} At the Perseus Project. although some minor variants like ''Sit Ei Terra Levis'' -abbreviated to ''SETL''- are attested,{{cite book|title=Manual of Classical Literature|first=Johann Joachim|last=Eschenburg|author-link=Johann Joachim Eschenburg|page=85|year=1836|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arAoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA85#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=Key and Biddle|place=Philadelphia|others=Translated from German by N.W. Fiske}} and excluding [[Africa (Roman province)|Roman Africa]] which developed its own stock formula (''Ossa Tibi Bene Quiescant'' -''OTBQ''- or similar),{{cite book|series=Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum|title=Inscriptiones Africae Latinae: Indicum|volume=Voluminis octavi supplementi partis quintae fasciculus tertius|page=300|first1=Gustav|last1=Wilmanns|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vk8bGATsJj0C&lpg=PP1&pg=PA300#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=1959|place=Berlin|publisher=[[Walter de Gruyter|Walter de Gruyter and Co]]|display-authors=etal}} At Google Books. in Latin [[epitaph]]s the phrase became formulaic, acquiring the aforementioned abbreviation. On the contrary, in [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] epitaphs, it never became such a fixed formula; it is found in various forms, e.g. {{lang|grc|γαῖαν ἔχοις ἐλαφράν, κούφη σοι κόνις ἥδε πέλοι, κούφη σεῖο γαῖ' ὀστέα κεύθοι.}}[[Sub verbo|s.v.]] {{LSJ|kou{{=}}fos|κούφη}}, {{LSJ|e)lafro/s|ἐλαφρά|ref}}. The Latin formula was usually located at the end of the inscription;{{cite book|first=Joshua|last=Scodel|title=The English poetic epitaph: commemoration and conflict from Jonson to Wordsworth|publisher=Cornell University Press|year=1991|isbn=0-8014-2482-8|page=82|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z6oULX3wr58C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}} at the beginning, another formulaic phrase was often used: ''[[Manes|Dis Manibus]]'', i.e. "To the spirits of the dead"; first thus, then shortened to ''Dis Man'' and finally to ''DM''. The latter, along with ''STTL'', had replaced in about mid-first century CE, the older model, common during the first century BCE and first century CE, of ending the inscription with ''[[wikt:hic#Latin|Hic]] [[wikt:situs#Latin|situs]] [[wikt:est#Latin|est]]'' or ''Hic [[wikt:sita#Latin|sita]] est'' ("he ''or'' she lies here"; abbreviated to ''HSE''), and the name of the dead person.{{cite book|title=Understanding Roman Inscriptions|first=Lawrence|last=Keppie|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FJmFAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT107#v=onepage&f=false|page=107|chapter=Gravestones and tomb monuments|publication-date=1991}}{{refn|group=n|A very common, through space and time, phrase in Greek and the analogue of the Latin one is {{lang|grc|[[wikt:Ἐνθάδε#Greek|Ἐνθάδε]] [[wikt:κεῖμαι#Greek|κεῖται]]}}, ''Enthade keitai'', "Here lies".}} ==Notes and references== '''Notes''' {{Reflist|group=n}} '''References''' {{Reflist}} ==See also== {{Commons category multi|Latin inscriptions|Ancient Greek inscriptions}} *[[Rest in peace|RIP]] *[[Memento mori]] *[[Necropolis]] *[[Stele]] *[[Roman funerals and burial]] *[[Ancient Greek funeral and burial practices]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Sit tibi terra levis}} [[Category:Latin inscriptions]] [[Category:Latin mottos]] [[Category:Greek inscriptions]] [[Category:Ancient Roman religion]] [[Category:Ancient Greek religion]] [[Category:Death in ancient Rome]] [[Category:Death customs]] {{AncientRome-stub}} {{Latin-vocab-stub}}

revision.text:
In '''''Spies v Smith''''', an important case in the [[South African law of succession]], the [[testator]] was [[mentally retarded]] and [[epileptic]], and had appointed the two daughters of his [[step-mother]] as his sole [[heir]]s. When the testator’s father died, he went to live with his [[uncle]]. Thereafter, the testator made a new [[will and testament|will]] appointing the sons of his uncle as his heirs.
The testator’s step-mother alleged that his uncle had unduly influenced him to pass this second will, but the court held that she did not discharge the requisite onus of proving such.
== See also == * [[South African law of succession]]
== References == * ''Spies v Smith'' 1957 (1) SA 539 (A).
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Inheritance]] [[Category:South African case law]] [[Category:1957 in case law]] [[Category:1957 in South African law]]
